elementText.text:
Fragment of a tablet concerning liabilities.
The content of this document cannot be reconstructed with certainty, given the poor condition of the tablet. In the first lines, one finds the name of a scribe (ṭupšarru), A. Then, a debt owed by B is mentioned – followed by fields (eqlu), houses (bītu) and possibly slaves (the word amīlūtu is lost because of a gap at the beginning of the line). In the following fragmentary passage the name of C is mentioned, followed by an unknown amount of silver that is at D’s disposal. E […] has received (našû) for the payment of the creditors (ana eṭēru ša rāšûti) […] In the final fragmentary passage three more names can be read: those of F1 and F2, and G. Names of 3 witnesses and 2 scribes: [Kabti-ilī-Marduk]//Atkuppu and [Libūru]//Nabûnnāya.
 
A = Libūru, scribe; B = Kidin-Marduk; C = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; D = Rēmūtu; E = Nabû-rīhtu-uṣur; F1 = Arad-Bēl; F2 = Ahhea; G = Marduk-šumu

elementText.text:
Establishment of a business partnership (harranu).
A1 and A2 invest 5 minas of silver and 130 pieces of empty barrels in a business partnership with two slaves: B1, slave of C and B2, slave of A2. The parties agree that the investors are entitled to a share in whatever the slaves make with the silver and the barrels in or out of town that equals that of the slaves. B1 and B2 should be fed (aklu akālu G, lit. "eat bread")) and clothed (mu%iptu katāmu N) for the entire period that they run the business (našpartu alāku), and this in addition (elat) to the household utensils that are (already) at their disposal. Names of xxx witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1 = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; A2 = Marduk-Šāpik-zēri/Nabû-šumu-iddin//Nādin-še'im; B1 = Šēpit-Nabû-aṣbat, slave of C; B2 = Nabû-dīni-epuš, slave of A2; C = Nabû-ahhē-iddin

elementText.text:
Warranty for a sold slave undertaken by the seller's son.
fA1, of her own free will, sold her slave C to B, for a full price (gamru) amounting to 1/2 mina and 5 shekels of silver. D, fA1’s son, guarantees against (suits brought by) a person acting unlawfully (sēhû) or a person claiming (pāqirānu) that C is a royal slave (arad šarrūtu) or a free person (mār banê). They guarantee for each other. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
fA1 = fBēlilitu/Bēl-ušēzib//Ša-nāšišu; B = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; C = Bazūzu, slave of fA1; D = Etellu/Balāssu//Dannēa, son of fA1

elementText.text:
Delivery and sale of onions
Concerns a total of (napharu) 2000 bundles (pītu) of onions belonging to A and originating from land labeled “from the mountain” (ina šadî), stretching from (ultu) the border of the field of the sailor C1 as far as the border of the field of the sailor C2, according to (ki) the preferential share (pūt zittu) of D1 and D2. A delivers (nadānu) these onions to B. Out of this 2000 bundles, a 100 were taken out (muššuru) because de facto they belong to E and another 100 were taken out because of bad quality (bīšu). The remainder (rēhu) of 1800 bundles A sells to B for 1 mina of silver per 660 bundles. The sale is prompted (aki) (lit. in accordance with) by the credit claim (rašûtu) of F1 and F2, the royal merchants (tamkār šarri) (against A). A bears the responsibility (pūt našû) for the safekeeping (maṣṣartu) and the good quality of the bundles till the 10th day of Nisan (I) by then B should have received the dates. Names of 2 witnesses, including F2 and the scribe.
 
A = Nabû-ēda-uṣur/Rahiannu; B = Nabû-kuṣranni/Gabbi-ina-qātē-Šamaš; C1 = Iṣṣurri/Zabidaja; C2 = Nabû-bān-ahi; D1 = Šamaš-ahhē-iddin/Ša-Nabûšu; D2 = Kināya/Nergal-hazuili; E=Bēl-iddin/Nabû-kul-lim; F1=Ili-ha-na-nu/Gabbi-ina-qātē-Šamaš; F2=Ardia/Nabû-aha-iddin

elementText.text:
Promissory note
B owes A 10 mina of medium quality (nuhhutu) silver of which 1/8 is alloy (bitqu), 71 kor of dates and 13 kor of barley. He will deliver the 13 kor of barley in Simān (III) of the 20th year. In Addar (XII) he will pay the 10 mina of silver and deliver the 71 kor of dates at the canal in Babylon without interest. The payment of the debt is secured by the pledge (maškanu) of the debtor’s 98 m2 house, located in the street of Hubur next to the houses of C1 and C2. The elat-clause is broken. Names of 8 witnesses and the scribe: Mušēzib-Marduk/Marduk-šumu-uṣur//Rab-banê. See also the receipts: MLC 689 (BRM 1 79 // Dar. 539), BM30255 (Dar. 545), BMUnknown(Dar536) and the promissory notes: BM30746 (Dar. 507); BM35338 (Dar. 462).
 
A = Bēl-uballiṭ/Bēl-ēṭir//Ir’anni; B = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; C1 = Ardia/Apkallu; C2 =Nergal-zēru-ibni

elementText.text:
Settlement of a silver debt.
Concerns the claim for payment (rašûtu) which A holds against B2 and (originally) B1, his father. The parties shall not sue each other (ragāmu D) in the future, as the entire debt (rašûtu gabbu) has been paid off (eṭēru, G Stat.). The document also relates to C's debt (to B1) for which his house had been given in antichresis as security: B1 had after-pledged this house to A together with his creditnote (u'iltu) and the securities it included, a.o. the guarantees given by Šulāya (=B1 or D?) and E that the debt be repaid (pūt eṭēri našû). This debt is settled as well (eṭēru, G Stat.). Any document (u'iltu) that should turn up in A's house about a claim for payment (rašûtu) to him against B2, Šulāya (=B1 or D?), C or E, is considered invalid (lit. "broken", hepû D, wr. hu-up-pa-a'). Names of 5 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Nergal-uballiṭ/Išum-uballiṭ//Bēl-ēṭiru; B1 = Šulāya/Nabû-zēru-ukīn//Egibi; B2 = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; C= (Marduk-)šāpik-zēri/Marduk-zāru-ibni//Šangû-Ninurta; D = Šulāya, without affiliation (either = B1 or another Šulāya); E = Arad-Bēl, without affiliation.

House rental.
A rents C’house to B for a yearly rental price of 24 shekels of stamped silver (ginnu). The house is located near (the one of) D1 and D2.

elementText.text:
Sale of slaves.
A, of his own free will, sells his female slaves fC1 and fC2, to fB for a total purchase price amounting to 3 minas of silver. The seller guarantees against (suits brought by) a person acting unlawfully (sēhû) or a person claiming (pāqirānu) that they are palace slaves (amat ekalli) or free persons (mār banê). Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Marduk-Šāpik-zēri/Bēl-uballiṭ//Nagiru; Bf = fIna-Esagila-rāmat/Zēria//Nabāya; fC1 = fBānitu-guzu; fC2 = fNinlil- Silīm

elementText.text:
About the property of a childless couple, possibly implying their divorce. Fragmentary.
A has married (ana aššūtu rašû) fB the 28th year of Nebuchadnezzar, but the couple did not have (rašû) any male or femal offspring (māru u mārtu). Together (itti ahāmeš), they wrote a document (ṭuppu) according to which their assets (nikkassu) and land (eqlu) belong to both of them (aḫata šunu). A court protocol (ṭuppu dīni) that belongs to the couple is mentioned, but here the tablet breaks off. List of witnesses, among which are C1,C2, and C3. Scribe: Šamaš-nāṣir/Bēl-ušallim//Miṣirāya.
 
A = …/Nabû-le’’i//Bā’iru; fB = fDamqāya/Ina-tēšê-ēṭir//Marduku, wife of A; C1 = Tabnēa/Nabû-le’’i//Bā’iru; C2 = Bēl-nāṣir/Nabû-le’’i//Bā’iru; C3 = Bēl-kāṣir/Šākin-šumi//Marduku

element.description: Museum number of cuneiform tablet

elementText.text:
Sale of land and receipt of the purchase price
A sells a built house (bītu epšu) measuring 6;0.6.13 sq. r (c. 84,94 m2) and located in Šuanna in Babylon to B.
1;0.0.2.13 r (c. 8,27 m) upper long side in the West near C’s house; 1;0.0.1.8 r (c. 7,66 m) lower long side in the East near D’s house; 1/2;0.0.6.13 r (c. 6,77 m) upper front in the North near E’s house; 1/2;0.0.6.15 r (c. 6,77 m) lower front in the South near the same plot of land – in total, 4;0.1.17 sq. r (c. 51,98 m2) of land, first measured area.
1/2;0.0.6.15 r (c. 6,77 m) upper long side in the North near the previous measured area, 1/2;0.0.6.12 r (c. 6,74 m) lower long side in the South near the … Canal; 1/2;0.0.2.4 r (c. 4,58 m) upper front in the West near C’s house; 1/2;0.0.3 r (c. 5 m) lower front in the East near D’s house – in total, 2;0.6.13 sq. r (35,94 m2) of land, second measured area.
A declares the equivalent for this land, 6;0.6.13 sq. r (c. 84,94 m2) in total, together with the seller B to be 1 mina and 15 shekels of silver for each 1/2 gar (12,5 m2) for a total purchase price amounting to 8 2/3 minas of silver. The buyer pays the total purchase price, plus 17 shekels of silver as additional payment and a garment for the lady of the (sold) house. B acknowledges that he has received in total 8 minas and 57 shekels of silver in pieces (šibirtu), and he is satisfied (apil). The parties agree that in future times there will be no claims or suits against each other, not even between members of their families – otherwise, any future claimant (pāqirānu) will have to repay twelvefold the silver he received. What remained of B's debt to Marduk's temple has been settled with the silver from the sale (kaspu šīm bīt šuāti ana makkūr Marduk nadin). Names of 9 witnesses, includingArad-Bēl/Bēl-uballiṭ, an oblate (širku) of Marduk and 2 temple scribes (tupšar bīt Marduk: Nabû-nāṣir/Sîn-tabni and Balāṭu/Arad-Ea). Name of the scribe: Libūru//Nabûnnāya.
 
A = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B = Šūzubu/Nabû-nādin-urri; C = Ardia/Apkallum; D = Nergal-zēru-ibni/Bēl-ile’’i; E = Bēl-ile’’i/Esagilāya; F = Arad-Bēl/Bēl-uballiṭ;

elementText.text:
Sale of a slave
A1 and his wife fA2 gave their slave C to B as a pledge for 50 shekels of silver, and they have set a due date (adannu) (for the payment of their debt). Now (since the term has passed by and they cannot pay), A1 and fA sell this slave to B, for an hariṣ-price amounting to 50 shekels of silver. The sellers guarantee against (suits brought by) a person acting unlawfully (sēhû) or a person raising claims (pāqirānu) about this slave. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1 = Itti-Nabû-balāṭu/Zēria; fA2 = fĒṭirtu/Ahhē-iddin, wife of A1; B = Tēšê-ēṭir/Nabû-le'’i//Šamaš-abārī; C = Nabûma-attū'a

elementText.text:
Promissory oath.
Beginning broken. The texts becomes legible while in the middle of a direct speech: " … A will bring along the men and […] who have been mustered for(?) B, and C, the agricultural worker (errēšu). He will hand them over to B in Opis."  Should he fail to do so, there will be a "reduction of the money bag" (miṭītu ša himti). D will pay in full the 14 1/3 minas of silver which are due to B. Names of xxx witnesses and the scribe: Nabū-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya
 
A = Silīm-Bēl/…//…; B = Nergal-šarru-uṣur/Bēl-šumu-iškun; C = Bādî-il; D = Nabû-kuzub-ilāni

elementText.text:
Fragment of a tablet concerning land rental.
A rents arable land (zēru) which he owns together with his brothers, located along the Harru-ša-Ina-qibi-Bēl and near C’s field, to B, who should perform gardening work (nukaribbūtu). Rest broken off. Names of 1+ witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; B = Nabû-Rē'ûšunu; C = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Talīmu

elementText.text:
Land rental.
The top of the tablet is broken off. The document concerns land located on the New Canal, rented by fA to B. The renter should irrigate it by drawing water from a well (ina dālu dalû). Both fA and B will enjoy the yield. The renter should dig a ditch above the canal. In a broken context, arable land (zēru) belonging to C is mentioned. The parties to the contract have taken one copy of the document each. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.
 
fA = fQudašu; B = Šulāya/Marduk-šumu-uṣur//Edu-ēṭir; C = Nergal-ēṭir

elementText.text:
Dowry gift. Substitute of promised dowry silver by a female slave.
A asked B to give his nubile (batultu) daugher fC in marriage (ana aššati nadānu) to his son D, and B accepted. In this document, the two take arrangements with regard to fC’s dowry (nudunnû), that will consist of: 1 mina of silver, 3 female slaves fE1, fE2, fE3 and household goods (udê bīti). However, B has given (nadānu) his female slave (qallatu) fF to A, in lieu of 2/3 of the 1 mina of dowry silver, corresponding to her complete value (ana šīm gamru). Then, B will give to A 1/3 of a mina of silver, the amount still due (babtu) on the one mina of silver, for the dowry to be completely paid (apālu G stat.). The parties to the contract have taken one copy of the document each. Names of 6 witness and the scribe: Nabû-mukīn-apli/Pir’//Uballissu-Gula.
 
A = Nabû-nādin-ahi/Bēl-ahhē-iddin//Arad-Nergal; B = Šumu-ukīn/Mušallimu; fC = fIna-Esagila-banât, daughter of B; D = Uballissu-Gula, son of A; fE1 = fLa-tubaššinnu, fE2 = fIna-ṣilli-Esabad, fE3 = fTaslimu; fF = fNanāya-kīširat, slave of B

elementText.text:
List of the freemen before whom a statement has been made.
The document lists the names of 6 freemen (mār-banê) in whose presence (ina pāni) A took over the responsibility (pūtu našû) for B toward (ina qātē) C. The list is dated and was issued in Bīt-Hahhuru.
 
A = Bēl-ēreš; B = Nabû-bullissu/Nidintu-Bēl; C = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu(//Egibi)

elementText.text:
Apprenticeship contract
A gives (nadānu) voluntarily his slave C to the stone cutter (purkullu) B, who is a slave (qallu) of the crownprince (mār šarri) Cambyses, during 4 years to learn the craft of stone cutter (purkullūtu).
B will teach C the craft of stone cutter. When he fails to do so, he will pay 20 shekels of silver (to the slave or his owner). When he teaches him in the 4 years the craft, … (broken off).
A will provide (katāmu D-stem) C with clothes (muṣiptu).
Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.
At the end of the document, after the list of witnesses, place and date, there is a fragmentary line mentioning 5 shekels of silver, the month Nisan (I) and the verb nadānu. 
 
A = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B = Hašdāya; C = Gûzu-ina-Bēl-aṣbat

elementText.text:
Interim settlement of accounts in court, within the framework of a business partnership.
Concerns the business partnership that A and his son B ran C and D as their co-workers (šutāpu) between Nabopolassar's 18th year and Nebuchadnezzar's 18th year, i.e. for at least 21 years. The partners settle their accounts before the judges (nikkassu epēšu);  It is decided (parāsu) that A and B (still) owe 50 shekels of silver, but that there are no other claims between them. The partnership is dissolved, an oath before the community (puhru) and the gods has been taken (nīšu zakāru), and their accounts are settled (epuš nikkassi qatû). All  promissory notes have been broken (i.e. invalidated). Names of xxx witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Nabû-mukīn-apli, father of B; B = Nabû-Bēlšunu, son of C; C = Šulāya/ŠNabû-)Zēru-ukīn(//Egibi); D = Mušēzib-Bēl (without affiliation)

elementText.text:
House rental.
A rents a house located at (ina) the Giššu-Gate to B for 3 years, for a yearly rental price amounting to 16 shekels of silver. The renter should caulk (šanû) and repair the roof. He should pay for the additional payment (nūptu) in Nisan (I), Dûzu (IV) and Kislim (IX); it is also agreed that half of the silver should be paid at the beginning of the year, and the remainder in the middle. The house is at the renter’s disposal from the 1st day of a month whose name is broken. B has already paid (verb broken off) 8 shekels of silver from the rental price. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B = Arad-Bēl/Kalbāya//Šumu-libši

elementText.text:
Dissolution of a business (partnership).
The document opens with a list of the equipment (udû) that A should give (nadānu) to fB, slave of C: 5 beds (eršu), 10 chairs (kussû), 3 tables (paššuru), 1 lamp stand (ingurēnu), 3 knives (sirpu), 1 iron spade (marru), 1 axe (qulmu), 1 fermenting vat (namzītu), 1 potstand (kankannu), 1 kettle (mušahhinu), 1 stand for a large vessel (šiddatu), 1 pair of tongs (maššānu), 1 chest (arannu) of ušukullatu - reed. They no longer own anything jointly. They will not renew litigation (târu) against each other. A is not allowed to take out (wr. ul <ú!>-še-UṢ-ṣu lit. will cause to go out) any of the equipment that belongs to fB between now and (adi) the end of Šabāṭ (XI). fB will pay the house rent (idu) from her own assets (ultu ramānišu nadānu). Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe. After the list of witnesses, the scribe, date and place, it is mentioned that A should give the document that states D’s credit claim to fB.
 
A = Marduk-iqīšanni (without affiliation); fB = fIshunnatu (without affiliation); C = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu(/Šulāya//Egibi); fD = fLillikanu (without affiliation)

elementText.text:
Purchase of land. Transfer of silver to the Esagila as compensatory payment.
The tablet records the purchase of agricultural land; the text has been divided into paragraphs, marked on the tablet by a line drawn at the end of each one (and indicated below in the paraphrase by LINE).
A purchases 24 Kor (324000 m2) of agricultural land (zēru) from the four brothers B1, B2, B3 and B4. The land is located in the open country (eqel ṣēri), and it consists partly of cultivated date garden (kirû gišimmarē zaqpi) and partly of cultivated as well as newly cleared land (mērešu u taptû) above and below the New Canal in from of the Enlil Gate, in the district (pīhatu) of Babylon. LINE
Its upper side in the West borders on (the property of) C1, C2, C3 and C4 and its lowers side in the East on (the property of) D. Its upper front in the North borders on the royal domain (eqel pīhat šarri) and its lower front on the dam of the hanšus (makallû ša hanšānē). LINE
2 kor (27000 m2) of this land is planted with big date palms whose value (šuqultu) corresponds to 9 minas of silver, i.e. 1 shekel of silver for each 6 2/3 gar (50 m2); 1;4.1.4 Kor (25050 m2) is planted with young date palms (tālāni) whose value (šuqultu) corresponds to 2 minas and 47 shekels of silver, i.e. 1 shekel of silver for each 20 GAR (150 m2). The remaining 20;0.4.2 Kor (271950 m2) is cultivated as well as newly cleared land (mērešu u taptû) whose value (šuqultu) corresponds to 10 minas and 4 1/3 shekels of silver, i.e. 1 shekel of silver for each 60 GAR (450 m2). A declares the equivalent for this land together with the sellers B1, B2, B3 and B4 (A itti B mahīra nabû) to be 21 minas and 51 1/3 shekels of silver for its total price, plus 28 2/3 shekels of silver as additional price (kî atar). LINE
In total, the four brothers have received 22 minas and 20 shekels of silver in pieces (šibirtu), corresponding to the total price for this field. The parties agree that in future times there will be no claims or suits against each other, not even between members of their families – otherwise, any future claimant (pāqirānu) will have to repay twelvefold the silver he received. B1, B2, B3 and B4, then, hand over this silver to the Esagila as compensatory payment (šullundu): they were in fact in debt for oxen that were part of Marduk’s property (makkūru). Names of 8 witnesses (the šākin-ṭēmi of Babylon and 7 judges) and of 4 scribes. The tablet shows multiple fingernail and seal impressions.
 
A = Nabû-ahhē-iddin; B1= Marduk-šākin-šumi/Marduk-ēṭir//Ēṭiru; B2 = Iqīša-Marduk/Marduk-ēṭir//Ēṭiru; B3 = Nabû-bān-ahi/Marduk-ēṭir//Ēṭiru; B4 = Nabû-ēṭir-napšāti/Marduk-ēṭir//Ēṭiru; C1 = Silīm-Bēl/Arad-Nergal//Ibni-ilu; C2 = Marduk-šumu-uṣur/Iddinnunu/Bēl-ēṭiru; C3 = Nabû-aplu-iddin/Marduk-šarrani//Itinnu; C4 = Kalbāya/Zākiru//Bēl-ēṭiru; D = Nabû-ēreš/Šulāya//Sîn-nādin-šumi

elementText.text:
Purchase of land.
Fragment of a tablet: only the final part of the text with the closing formulas is preserved. The buyer, B, acknowledges that he has received the full amount of silver that was due for his field and he is satisfied (apālu  G Stat). The parties agree that in future times there will be no claims or suits against each other; should someone from the Andahar (i.e. the seller’s) family complain against this purchase, the claimant (pāqirānu) will have to repay twelvefold the received silver. One final clause states that should a claim (paqāru) arise (bašû N) C, B’s brother, will clear the property (murruqu) and will hand it over to the buyer, A. Names of 2+ witnesses; name of the scribe lost.
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; B = Nabû-uballiṭ/Lūṣi-ana-nūr//Andahar; C = Iddin-Bēl/Lūṣi-ana-nūr//Andahar

elementText.text:
Agreement about the measurement of a field after the sale and after the seller’s death.
A purchased 1 kor (13500 m2) of arable land (zēru) from B (ana kaspi mahāru) in Šabāṭ of Cambyses 2nd year. Part of the land is already cultivated (mērešu), while the other part is newly prepared for cultivation (taptû) and it includes scattered date palms. On the day of the purchase, they put the agreement down in writing in a sealed document; the buyer took a written and sealed copy of the agreement (kanāku - leqû), which also specifically clarifies (šūdû [edû]) that they will check the measurements of that field. Should it be found larger or smaller (atru u maṭû) than what was originally calculated, they will compensate each other (ahāmeš apālu ). However, the seller died before the land could be measured. After a gap in the tablet, the text resumes and mentions the name of C, possibly a neighbour whose plot of land extended up to the dam of the hanšû (makallû ša hanšānē). The passage is too broken to determine the exact context. At the end of the document, A agrees with D (no doubt the seller’s legal successor) that they will not make claims against each other about the measurement of the field. To seal the deal, they both pronounce an oath. Names of 6 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B = Bazūzu/Etellu//Išparu; C = Marduk-rēmanni/N[abû-…]; D = Bēl-ahhē-iddin

elementText.text:
Testimonies (a.o. under oath) about the role of a slave as witness. Fragmentary.
A large part of this fragmentarily preserved document consists of declarations in direct speech in which the role of C, witness to a property transfer, is discussed. In the opening lines, in fact, A1 declares under oath (nīš zakāru) before the judges (dayyānu) that he does not know (idû) C, the third witness listed in the tablet (ṭuppu) that records the transfer of assets (nikkassu) to fB2. The name of the donor is lost in a lacuna, but can safely be reconstructed as B, and if we assume that fB2 the beneficiary, was his wife, we are dealing with a property transfer between husband and wife. Then A2 testifies (verb is broken off) before D, the governor (šākin ṭēmi) of Babylon that when B1 (the donor) fell ill, he sent E to someone (possibly C), asking him to come over. He (possibly C) eventually went to B1 (ana pāni alāku) and they decided not to bring suit against A2 (itti dabābu). The following fragmentary passage mentions B1’s arable land (zēru) and building plots (qanû), and again states that "they did not bring suit". It seems that a dispute had arisen about some of the assets that B1had transferred to fB2, but that it eventually did not lead to a formal lawsuit. In the final lines, mostly lost, the role of C is brought up again in directly quoted testimonies by persons whose identity cannot be established. It is claimed that he could strictly speaking not act as witness (šībū), considering the fact that he is a slave (qallu šū). Someone apparently allowed him to be listed (šaṭāru) among the witnesses since they were both present (amāru, lit. "to see") when the purchase price was paid (mahīru nadânu). Finally, in a direct speech someone states that although B1's tablet has been changed (enû), he/she remembers (hasāsu) to whom it had been given. On the lower edge of the tablet there are the seal impressions of 5 judges: F1, F2, F3, F4, F5.
 
A1 = (name broken off)]; A2 = (name broken off); B1 = Nabû-mukīn-apli;  fB2 = fBunanītu; C = Nergal-šumu-iddin/Nabû-šumu-ibni//Rišana-Esangila; D = Nabû-iddin, šākin ṭēm Bābili; E = Nabû-ēṭir-napšāti; F1 = Nergal-Bānûnu, judge; F 2 = Nabû-ahhē-iddin, judge; F 3 = Nabû-šumu-ukīn, judge; F 4 = Bēl-ēṭir, judge; F 5 = Nabû-balāssu-iqbi, judge

elementText.text:
Resettlement of claims among business partners.
Concerns A1's and A2's claim (rašûtu) for at least 150 bundles (pītu) of onions (exact amount is broken off) that they hold against B within the framework of a business partnership (harrānu). The onions are C's investment in the business. A promissory note stating B's indebtness has been issued (u'iltu e'ēlu). In the present document A1 transfers his part of the claim to A2 (pāni dagālu) who thus becomes the sole titleholder (ana muhhi e'ēlu). Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe: Bēl-iddin/Bēl-upahhir//Dābibi.

A1 = Nabû-mukīn-apli/Bēl-ušallim//Arkat-ilī; A2 = Nabû-ušallim/Īnia; B = Šumu-ukīn/Zēria; C = Silīm-Bēl/Bēl-nādin-apli//Kānik-bābi

elementText.text:
Receipt for barley. Partial payment of a debt
Concerns the repayment of B's debt of 86;2.3 kor of barley to A. Part of it, namely 24;2.3 is paid directly to A in accordance with the promissory note; another part is paid to one of A's creditors, D, as follows: he receives from B a slave named C and worth (šīmu) 18 kor of barley as well as 6;2.3 kor of barley. More on the repayment of this debt at BM30325 (= Nbk 212). Names of xxx witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Rēmūt/Nabû-šumu-iškun//Gahal; B = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; C = Bēl-šullimanni; D = Nabû-ēṭir/Rēmūt-Bēl

elementText.text:
Hiring of a person
A1 and A2 will travel overland (ana ṣēri alāku) with B, the slave of C  for a monthly payment of 4 ½ shekels of silver, leaving this very day (the 11th of Ayyar (II)). Their parents (C and fD) receive (maḫāru) their (children’s) one-month salary (idu), namely the 4 ½ shekels of silver, from B. The person who violates the contract (nabalkutu) shall pay 4 ½ shekels of silver. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1 = Nādin(/Marduk-nāṣir//…); A2 = …/Marduk-nāṣir]//…; B = Ṣilli-Bēl, slave of C; C = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; D = Marduk-nāṣir, father of A1 and A2; fE = Ṭubūtu, mother of A1 and A2

elementText.text:
About a slave sale: delivering obligation.
D sold three slaves to B: C, for 1 mina and 30 shekels of silver, plus E1 and E2 for 3 minas and 30 shekels of silver. By the end of Dûzu, the seller's brother A will bring one of the sold slaves (C), and deliver him (abāku-ma nadānu) to B. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Mušēzib-Bēl/Bēl-ahhē-erība/Rē'i-sīsê; B = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; C = Nabû- kiššunu; D = Bēlšunu/Bēl-ahhē-erība/Rē'i-sīsê; E1 = Nabû-killanni; E2 = Ninlil-šadū'a

elementText.text:
Deposition.
Concerns A's legal efforts to take possession of four slaves as compensation for having repaid a debt on behalf of C1  and his wife. In Nabonidus’ 8th regnal year, B raised a claim against C1 (concerning) 2 1/3 minas of silver, and issued a promissory note against him and his wife fC2. He took their children fD1, fD2, fD3 and D4, their house and every property they held inside and outside the city as a pledge. They guaranteed for each other and A guaranteed for the payment as well. Now, C1 did not pay; he and his wife died – after which B brought A in front of Nabonidus' judges who looked into the written legal evidence (riksu). They entitled (rašû Š) A to those 2 1/3 minas of silver, apart from the silver that he had previously given to the creditor.  A paid the silver to B, he has given A the promissory note as well as a copy (gabrû) of the process protocol (ṭuppi dīni). The judges referred A back (nahāsu Š) to C1’s house to recup his silver from the inheritance. A then brought E1, C1’s heir (iarītu) and fE2, his sister-in-law, before the judges. They looked into his documents and E1 and fF declared that they don't want to take up C1’s inheritance (iaritūtu epēšu) and agree that A takes as pay-off (šalāmu G) from C's property (nikkassu) and from the slaves (amīlūtu) that had been pledged to him. Thus they (fem. pl.) undid A's document (ṭuppu paṭāru G; partly uncl.) and … (verb broken off).  From the following fragmentary passage, that continues to report A’s speech, it becomes clear that he took possession (abāku) of the four slaves (fD1, fD2, fD3 and D4 ) for the 3 minas and 50 shekels of silver, covering future as well as previous claims against C1’s and fC2. As a result the slaves are at his disposal (ina pāni). His document related to their status of free persons (mār banê) is sealed. The end of the plaintiff's speech is damaged: it mentions the issue of bringing along witnesses (muddû abāku) and taking an oath by E1-2, (C1’s two nephew) and G. This is followed by a break of about 10 lines. At the end the judges, having heard the witnesses (mukinnūtu)  gave (verb reconstructed) fD1, mother of fD2  and the slaves … fD2 to A. A month later the case is readdressed in BM30645 (=Nbn 668). Names of 7 judges and 2 scribes; third listed witness-judge is Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi.

 
A = Bēl-rēmanni/Lâbāši-Marduk//Ašgandu; B = Nabû-šumu-ukīn/Ibnāya//Šangû-Nanāya; C1 = Arad-Gula/Nabû-ile’’i//Bā'iru; fC2 = fDamqāya, wife of C1; fD1 = fAna-Tašmētu-atkal, slave of C1 and fC2; fD2 = fAmtia, daughter of fD1; fD3 = fNanāya-ana-bītišu, daughter of fD1; D4 = Zababa-iddina, son of fD1; E1 = Nergal-uballiṭ(/Bēl-nāṣir//Bā'iru), nephew and heir of C1; E2 = Rīmūt-Bēl(/Bēl-nāṣir//Bā'iru), nephew of C1; fF = fReminni-Ištar, sister of fC2; G = ... /Gahal.

elementText.text:
Injunction
On Abu (V), 2nd,  A must hand over his witness at the entrance to B’s (i.e. the canal inspector’s = gugallu) house. He will testify against C, telling if he took A’s TÚG.KUR.RA-garment and ša-qabli garment. If the witness will leave his deposition, then C will give the garments back to A. If he will not testify, then C will go unpunished. If the accused will fail to be present on Abu (V), 2nd, he will be sentenced to give back the TÚG.KUR.RA-garment as well as the ša-qabli garment even without any witness. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Imbēa/Nabû-šumu-ukīn//Mukallimu; B = Bēl-iddin, canal inspector (gugallu); C = Arrabi/Saggilu//Mar-banê

elementText.text:
About a debt for silver. Warranty. Fragmentary.
Concerns the open debt (lit. "in the countryside" ina ṣēri) for silver, its interest, and x [(x)] (=uncl.) which A issued (e’ēlu) against B1 and B2. The present document confirms that the debtors actually received (eṭēru) all of it from A. They assume warranty for each other. It is further agreed that A is allowed to take away (našû) the 2 minas of silver <at?>  their … (<ana?> ṣibûtu) (partly uncl.), besides the promissory note that is issued against them, till the end of the year (followed by a broken passage). Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; B1 = Marduk-erība/Nādin; B2 = Iqīšāya/Bēl-kāṣir//Šangû-parakki

elementText.text:
Security for a silver debt.
B owes 3 minas and 14 shekels of silver to A. He secures this debt in various ways. First he pledges a house that he himself took from C in antichresis (ana maškanūti ṣabātu). So, this is a case of after-pledge (German: Unterverpfandung). As extra security, he gives A the document recording C's debt (adi u'ilti) and the warranties it includes (pūt našû). Further he agrees to pay 2 ¼ shekels of silver as rent for the house to A from the 1st of Šabāṭu (XI) of the 12th year onwards and till the debt is fully repaid. Most likely, the rent guarantees that B can continue living in the house. Finally, he pledges fD, his slave-cook (lúMU qallu) and his entire property in and outside of the city. No other creditor shall exercise any rights over the pledged person and objects until A has received the full repayment of the debt. Eventually, B's son took over the debt (BM31052 = Nbk. 142) and its final settlement occured 4 ½ years after the current document (BM30348 = Nbk. 172). Names of xxx witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Nergal-uballiṭ/Išum-uballiṭ//Bēl-ēṭiru; B = Šulāya/Nabû-zēru-ukīn//Egibi; C = (Marduk-)Šāpik-zēri/Marduk-zēru-ibni//Šangû -Ninurta; fD = fIna-ṣilli-Bēl, cook (lúMU) and slave (qallu) of B

elementText.text:
Promissory note for silver.
B owes 26 1/24 shekels of silver to A, to be paid at the end of Addar (XII). He should pay(*) with the silver that he will get from selling his field (eqlu). This sale is recorded in BM33090 (= Nbn 687). Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe: Bēl-iddin/Bēl-šumu-iškun/Sîn-tabni (debtor). (*) lit. "(the creditor) will be paid" (šalāmu G).

A = Marduk-nāṣir/ Iddinaya/ Gahal; B = Bēl-iddin/ Bēl-šumu-iškun/ Sîntabni

elementText.text:
Court protocol: dispute over the sale of a slave
fA said thus to the judges of king Nabonidus: "In the month Abu (V) of Neriglissar’s 1st regnal year, I sold my slave C to B for 1/2 mina and 5 shekels of silver. He wrote a promissory note (u‘iltu) and did not pay the silver". The judges heard (the plaintiff’s statement), brought (abālu) B and had him stand before them (uzuzzu Š). B showed (kullumu) the judges the contract (riksu) which he contracted (rakāsu) with fA and that proved that he had paid off (eṭēru) the remaining silver of the slave’s price. D1, D2 and D3 testified (kânu D) in front of the judges that their mother fA had been repaid (eṭēru). The judges have discussed the case and established a fine amounting to 1/2 mina and 5 shekels of silver, the same sum she demanded, to be paid by fA. They have given the silver to B on the basis of this just decision. Related to this matter are also BM30574 (= Ner 23) and BM30454 (= Ner 42) Names of 6 judges and the scribe: Nergal-bānûnu//Rab-banê. The unsealed tablet YBC16313 seems to be a duplicate.
 
fA = fBēlilitu/Bēl-ušēzib//Ša-nāšīšu(!), mother of D1, D2 and D3; B = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; C = Bazūzu; D1 = Zēria, son of fA; D2 = Nabû-šumu-līšir, son of fA; D3 = Etellu, son of fA

elementText.text:
Promissory note for barley without interest.
B owes 9;0.2 kor of barley to A in an interest-free loan (hubuttutu), to be delivered without interest (ina qaqqadi) in Simān (III) of the following year. Delivery is due in Babylon at the entrance to the depot (kalakku) and according to B's measure. Should a previous promissory note about the barley debt turn up (elû) it is to be considered invalid (hepû, lit. "broken"). A short remark on the tablet's left edge points out that the above arrangement does not pertain (ša la) to a promissory note for barley that is held against C. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe: Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi.
 
A = Šulāya/Zēru-ukīn//Egibi; B = Bēl-iqīša/Zēru-ukīn//Munnabittu; C = Karbazakka (without affiliation)

elementText.text:
Purchase of land
The tablet records the purchase of agricultural land; the text has been divided into paragraphs, marked on the tablet by a line drawn at the end of each one (and indicated below in the paraphrase by LINE).
A purchases 0;1.5.4 Kor (5250 m2) of agricultural land (zēru) located in the open country (eqel ṣēri) from B. It consists of cultivated date garden (kirû gišimmarē zaqpi) bearing fruit (iṣṣi bilti), land cultivated with big as well as young date palms (tālāni), located in front of the Zababa Gate in the district (pīhatu) of Babylon. LINE
The upper long side in the North borders on (the property of) C and the lower side in the South on (the property of) A, D1 and D2; the upper front in the West borders on (the property of) E1 and E2, the lower front in the East is adjacent to the Sukullâtu-street. LINE
A declares the equivalent for this land together with the seller B (A itti B mahīra nabû išām) to be 1 mina and 10 shekels of silver. He gives (nadānu) B the total purchase price plus 1 shekel as additional payment (kî atri). LINE
The seller acknowledges that he has received (mahāru) in total 1 mina and 11 shekels of silver in pieces (šibirtu), and he is satisfied (apālu  G Stat). The parties agree that in future times there will be no claims or suits against each other, not even between members of their families – otherwise, any future claimant (pāqirānu) will have to repay twelvefold the silver he received. The field will be measured: should it be found smaller or larger than what was originally calculated they will compensate each other (ahāmiš apālu ) according to the field-price ratio (mahīru) they agreed upon. Fingernail impressions (ṣupru) of the seller B, instead of his seal impression (kunukku). Names of 6 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; B = Bēl-ušallim/Šumu-ukīn//Sîn-šadûnu; C = Marduk-zēru-ibni/Nabû-balāssu-iqbi//Sîn-šadûnu; D1 = Rēmūtu; D2 = Bēl-iddin; E1 = Nabû-mukīn-apli/Nādin-ahi//Adad-šumu-ēreš; E2 = Bēlšunu/Nādin-ahi//Adad-šumu-ēreš

elementText.text:
Purchase of land.
The tablet records the purchase of agricultural land; the text has been divided into paragraphs, marked on the tablet by a line drawn at the end of each one (and indicated below in the paraphrase by LINE).
fA purchases 0;0.5 Kor (2250 m2) of agricultural land (zēru) in the open country (eqel ṣēri) from B. This is a cultivated date garden (kirû gišimmarē zaqpi) bearing fruit (iṣṣi bilti). It is the seller’s share (zittu) in land that he did not divide (zu’uzu) with his older brother C, his younger brother D, and his uncle E, and is located in Šuppatu in the district (pīhatu) of Babylon. LINE
Its upper side in the North borders on (the propery of) F1 und F2, its lower side in the South on (the property of) G; its upper front in the West borders on the bank of the Euphrates (kišād nār Puratti) and its lower front in the East on (the property of) H.
fA declares the equivalent for this land together with the seller B (A itti B mahīra nabû išām) to be 1 shekel of silver for each 1 1/2 SILÀ (112,5 m2). The buyer gives (nadānu) the total purchase price (šīmišu gamrūtu) of 20 shekels of silver, plus 2 shekels as additional payment (kî atri). B acknowledges that he has received (mahāru) in total 22 shekels of silver in pieces (šibirtu), and he is satisfied. The parties agree that in future times there will be no claims or suits against each other, not even between members of their families – otherwise, any future claimant (pāqirānu) will have to repay twelvefold the silver he received. A very damaged line mentions equal shares; the context however is unclear. Then the text continues establishing that the field will be measured, and should it be found larger or smaller than what was originally calculated they will compensate each other (ahāmiš apālu) according to the field-price ratio (mahīru) they agreed upon. B has also received (eṭēru) from fA an amount of silver (not written in this tablet) which was due to him for the price of the harvest (šīm ebūri) in Cyrus’ xth year from a small plot of land (3+2 BÁN = 0.0.5+ kor or c. 2250 m2). C, his older brother, has taken (leqû) a broken amount of silver (x shekels) as gift (qīštu). Fingernail impressions (ṣupru) of the seller B, instead of his seal impression (kunukku). Names of 6 witnesses and the scribe.
 
fA = fBu’ītu/Nabû-bān-ahi//Šangû-Gula; B = Nabû-uballiṭ/Nabû-mukīn-zēri//Asû; C = Iddin-Marduk/Nabû-mukīn-zēri//Asû; D = Nergal-zēru-ibni/Nabû-mukīn-zēri//Asû; E = Mukīn-Marduk, uncle of B; F1 = Zēria; F2 = Nā'id-Marduk; G = Tabnēa/Ina-tēšê-ēṭir//Asû; H = Kidinnu/Zēria//Šangû-Gula

elementText.text:
Fixation of interest on a silver debt.
B owes 3 ½ minas of silver to A, on which he should pay a yearly interest of 20% on a monthly basis. The debtor is explicitly identified as brother of C. De facto, this concerns a debt between uncle (debtor) and nephew (creditor).  In addition, there is an earlier document about the issue of warranty. Names of xxx witnesses and the scribe
 
A = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B = Bēl-kēšir/Šulāya//Egibi, brother of C; C = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi

elementText.text:
Warranty for sold slaves undertaken by a third party and the buyer's promise to pay the purchase price.
fA, of her own free will, sold 2 slaves to B for the full price (gamru) of 3 minas of silver and received (mahāru) the silver. The first slave, C1, is marked (uṣṣuru), has split ears (ša uznēšu li-tu-ut-x = letâtu, from letû)(*) and has a white (birth)mark (pūṣu) between/in (ina) his eyes; the second slave C2 is also marked. D guarantees against prior claims (uškûtu) related to these slaves. Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe.
(*) CAD U/W, p. 288. Or else read: is marked (uṣṣuru) on his ears and cheeks (lētu).
 
fA = fTabannu/Niqūdu(?); B = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; C1 = Nergal-ašarēd(?), slave of fA; C2 = Nabû-alsika-abluṭ, slave of fA; D = Nabû-tattannu/Tabnēa//Bēl-ēṭir

elementText.text:
Promissory note for silver, within the framework of a business partnership (harrānu). Pledge of slaves and general pledge.
B owes 2 minas 7 ½ shekels of medium quality silver, of which one-fifth is alloy (hummušu) and 50 shekels of low quality silver, of which one-twelfth to A (girrētu). It is an interest-free loan (hubbutatu). The payment is secured by the pledge of the debtor’s property in and outside the city, as well as a family of slaves (D, his wife and children). No other creditor shall exercise any rights over the pledged property until A has received the full repayment of his debt. The debtor swears by Bēl and Nabû that he will pay before Šabāṭ (XI) has passed (etēqu). The (indebted) silver is what C invested in the business partnership with A (and which the latter now borrows to B). The debt is mentioned again in a document that was drafted a week later (BM30634). A year later the pledged slaves are sold to A's wife, cf. BM41396 (=Nbk. 34, reedited Wunsch 1993, 16). Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe: Itti-Nabû-balāṭu/Nergal-uballiṭ//Sagilāya.
  
A = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; B = Mušēzib-Marduk/Marduk-ēṭir//Nappāhu; C = Širiktu(/Nūrea//Dannea); D = Bēl-eṭranni (slave of B?)

elementText.text:
About the title to a promissory note for silver.
A drew up (e’ēlu) the document (u’iltu) about the 34 shekels of medium quality (nuhhutu) silver of which 1/8 is alloy (bitqu) that is due from B. However, it was C who provided A with the silver for the loan (lit. these 34 shekels of silver belong to C)  and it was he who asked for (ana naši ṣibûti) the document to be drawn up (e’ēlu). A has therefore promptly returned it and handed it over (târu D-nadānu) to C. Wherever a duplicate of the promissory note turns up, it belongs to C. See also BM33131 (Dar 489). Fragmentary list of witnesses and the scribe: Nabû-uṣuršu/Kittia//Šangû-Ea.
 
A = Bēl-ittannu/Iqīša-Marduk//Ur-Nanna; B = Itti-Bēl-lummir/Ša-Nabû-šū; C = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi

elementText.text:
Settlement of a law suit about client people
Concerns the law suit (dīnu), which A2 and his mother (fA2) raised (ragāmu) against B about fC1, her children and C2, clients in his (B's) house (nīšū bīti). B feared (adāru) the litigation and did not show up (alāku) in court. Instead, he promptly returned some of the contested clients, namely fC1 and her children, to the litigants. He took an oath and for (kum) the third client (C2) who passed away while in B's house, he paid 4 minas of silver to the litigants. He made the final settlement (amirtu epēšu) with the litigants. Any claims (dibbu) concerning reeds, slaves and the slave-wages (mandattu) has thus been settled (qatû) amongst the parties who shall not raise a new law suit against each other (ana muhhi ahameš ragāmu). The defendant and the litigants have sworn by Bēl and Nabû and the majesty (adû) of Darius that they shall not reconsider (nahāsu) the matter that they negotiated (epēšu) (wording of the oath in direct speech). The document ends by stating that A1 and his mother received payment (eṭēru) for the slave-wages. Names of 12 witnesses, a.o. Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; an Imbukean, and a Rimean; and the scribe: Nabû-aplu-iddin/Nabû-šumu-iškun//Šangû-Nin-Eanna.
 
A1 = Karēa/ Bēl-ile’’i/Ahūtu; fA2 = fNuptāya/Nabû-balāssu-iqbi; B = Nergal-ahu-iddin/Ahhēa;  fC1 = fKuzbāya, slave; C2 = Bēl-uṣuršu (T. Nabû-ṣur-šú)

elementText.text:
Receipt for silver. Partial payment of a debt. Fragmentary.
It concerns the promissory note (u’iltu) that records A’s claim (rašûtu) against B and from which A now receives (mahāru) 5 mina of silver from B. A fragmentary passage mentions that this claim comes in addition (elat) to the 4½ mina of medium quality (nuhhutu) silver of (broken name) to A that are part of (ina) A’s claim. Fragmentary names of 3 witnesses and the name of the scribe: …/Ahu-ibni. The parties have each taken a copy of this document.
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; B = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Marduk-zēru-ibni//…

A = Marduk-rēmanni/Marduk-ušallim?; B = Arad-Nergal/Marduk-ēṭir//Ša-ṭābtišu; C1 = Iddinnunu/lú.GIŠ.HA (rd. lúšu?-HA = Bā'iru?); C2 = Nabû-mušētiq-uddê/Bēl-ahhē-ibni//Rab-banê; D1 = Nidinti-Bēl, son of A; D2 = Silīm-Bēl, son of A; D3 = Balāṭu, son of A; E = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi

elementText.text:
Undertaking to deliver dates and its by-products
Concerning the dates that are the estimated income from imposts (imittu) from land on the New Canal for the 9th year of Nabonidus and due to A1 and A2.
B1, B2, who is the slave of A1, B3 and B4 will deliver in Babylon at the Canal each respectively 63 kor of dates (B1), 43 kor of dates (B2), 33 kor of dates (B3), and 32 kor of dates (B4). The next passage is fragmentary and deals with the by-products of the date production. For each kor of dates, they will deliver spathes (tuhallu), … (broken), and darīku-containers, … (broken). This is in addition to (elat) the 7 kor of dates of the 8th year that are still due from B4. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1 = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; A2 = Bēl-nādin-apli/Nergal-ušallim// Ile’’i-Marduk; B1 = Arad-Bēl/ Kabtia//Pappāya; B2 = Nabû-rīhtu-uṣur; B3 = Nergal-ušallim/Tabnēa//Sîn-karābī-išme;  B4 = Gimillu/Šākin-šumi//AradNergal

elementText.text:
Sale of land and receipt of purchase price.
[…] in front of the Uraš Gate in the district (pīhatu) of Babylon: upper long side in the North near (the property of) A, the buyer, lower long side in the South near the land of the Uraš Temple; upper front in the West along the bank (kišādu) of the Euphrates, lower front in the East along the Piqūdu Canal. This land (whose surface area is lost in a lacuna) is made up partly of land planted with trees (zēru zaqpu) valued at 1 mina and 20 shekels of silver, and partly of wasteland (kišubbû) valued at 12 shekels of silver. A declares the equivalent for this land together with the seller B (A itti B mahīra nabû išām) to be 1 mina and 32 shekels of silver, plus 2 shekels of silver as additional payment (kî atri). B acknowledges that he has received (eṭēru) 1 mina and 32 shekels of silver in pieces (šibirtu) and he is satisfied (apil). The parties agree that in future times there will be no claims or suits against each other, not even between members of their families – otherwise, any future claimant (pāqirānu) will have to repay twelvefold the silver he received. The field will be measured, and should it be found larger or smaller than what was originally calculated they will compensate each other (ahāmiš apālu) according to the field-price ratio (mahīru) they agreed upon. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B = Nabû-aplu-iddin/Marduk-šumu-iddin//Šangû-Gula

elementText.text:
Sale of slaves.
A, of his own free will, sells his female slaves fC1 and fC2 to B for a hariṣ-price amounting to 54 shekels of silver. The seller guarantees against (suits brought by) a person acting unlawfully (sēhû) or a person claiming (pāqirānu) that these slaves are a royal slaves (arad šarrūtu) or free persons (mār banê). The silver from this sale is used to pay E1, E2 and E3 for their claim (rašūtu) against D (A’s father). Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Nabû-kāṣir/Nabû-zēru-līšir; B = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; fC1 = fDidinnatu;  fC2 = fAlikšu-lūmur; D = Nabû-zēru-līšir, father of A; E1 = Mušēzib-Marduk/Marduk- ēṭir//Nappāhu; E2 = Marduk-šumu-iddin/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Nappāhu; E3 = Nabû-nādin-apli/…-iddin//...-ēreš

elementText.text:
Promissory oath.
A1 and A2 swear by the gods Bēl and Nabû and by the majesty (adû) of king Darius to B:  "We will certainly bring along C1, who while on the run(?) has been living with us(?)  in Gubba since Cyrus’ 8th regnal year (the date is partially broken, day and month are unknown), and who changed his name into C2, [...]; fD, who lives with him, and E1, [E2] and fE3, (her children?), who (live?) with her […]. We will hand them over to F." Should they fail to bring back C1, they will still give fD and her children to F. Names of xxx witnesses, including W1 who comes from Huna (lúhu-na-a-a), W2, W3, W4, W5 who comes from Imbukku (uruim-bu-ku-ú-a-a), W6, W7, W8, and W9. Name of the scribe: Nabû-zēru-ibni//Egibi.
 
A1 = Ahu-erība/Bēl-iddin//…; A2 = Nabû-šarru/Ahhēšu//Zabdâ; B = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; C1 = Nabû-Rē'û; C2 = Nabû-ittannu; fD = fŠūṣiā-naqqarat(?)/…; E1 = [the name is broken off]; E2 = [the name is broken off]; fE3 = fPalitu; F = Marduk-nāṣir (=B?); W1 = Bēl-itti-Nabû/Nabû-ibni, the man from Huna (lúhu-na-a-a); W2 = Bēl-ittannu/Bēl-uballiṭ//lúIN-RI-KA-AN-MEŠ; W3 = Bēl-ahhē-iddin/Bēl-zēri//Šigûa; W4 = Sîn-ibni/Sîn-šarru-uṣur; W5 = Sassû, the man from Imbukku (uruim-bu-ku-ú-a-a); W6 = Megabaraššu (wr. mme-e-ga-ba-ra-áš-šú);  W7 = Katutu ; W8 = Menâ  ; W9 = Buriuqu;  G = Nabû-zēru-ibni/Egibi

elementText.text:
Land rental.
A rents (ana sūtu nadānu) 3 Kor (40500 m2) of newly cleared land (zēru taptû), from the upper dam (pariktu) [...] on the Banītu Canal to the lower border (miṣru) [...] of D, to B (C’s slave), for a number of years which is lost in a lacuna of the tablet. The renter will give him 7 Kor (1260 l) of barley (uṭṭatu) per year, as well as an unknown amount of bunches of straw (makṣaru ša tibni), in one instalment. Whoever breaks the contract shall pay 1 mina of silver. The renter will deliver to the landlord one mutton (UDU.NITA) of good quality. The parties to the contract have taken one copy of the document each. Names of 6 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; B = Sîn-ibni; C = Mardukāya; D = Iddin-Nabû/Zuzia//…

elementText.text:
Warranty for a donkey within the framework of a sale.
Concerns a six-year old black donkey whose ear from the cheek upwards is split (batqu), which A sold (ana kaspi nadānu) to B for its full price (gamru), 2/3 minas (or perhaps 5/6) of white medium-quality silver of which 1/8 is alloy. The seller assumes warranty against the status of holder of prior claims (uškûtu) for this donkey and acknowledges that he received (mahāru) full payment for the animal from the buyer and he is paid off (eṭēru). Names of 6 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Iddin-Nabû/Bunene-ibni; B = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi

elementText.text:
Oath. Undertaking to deliver a person.
The tablet concerns D, who is at A’s disposal. A, servant (qallu) of C, swears (tamû) to B before Bēl, Nabû and king Darius that on the 10th day of Ṭebēt (X) he will bring along (abāku) D, C’s x x (uncl.), and hand him over (nadānu) to B. Names of 11 witnesses and the scribe: Marduk-bēlšunu/[…]//Šangû-Ea. After the date and place an additional 12th witness Taddidu/Iqūpu//Egibi is mentioned.
 
A = Nabû-ittanni/[PN], servant (qallu) of C; B = Širku/Iddināya//Egibi (aka Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi); C = Asapašinni; D = Bēl-lū-šulluma

elementText.text:
Deposition before the freemen (mār banê).
A in the presence (ina pāni) of the freemen (mār-banê) takes over the responsibility (pūtu našû) for B toward (ina qātē) C. He guarantees that the silver that B owes to C will be paid (eṭēru) according to (akī) C’s promissory note (u’iltu) by Tašrīt (VII) of the 20th year of king Darius. Names of 5 witnesses and the scribe: Bēl-iddin/Nabû-nādin-ahi.
 
A = Ahušunu/Bēl-ēṭir; B = Nidintu/Kuššāya; C = Širku/Iddināya (aka Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu)

elementText.text:
Apprenticeship contract
fA gives (nadānu) C1, her husband’s (C2) slave, to B during 5 years to learn the art of weaving (ina išparūtu). B will teach C1 all about the weaver’s craft. fA will give C1 each day for 1 year (adi ṭuppi ṭuppi) 1 sila of bread and clothing. When he doesn’t teach the weaver’s craft, he will pay each day 0;0.1.0 kor barley to the slave as his wage (mandattu). The party that breaches the contract (nabalkutu), has to pay (nadānu) 20 shekels of silver. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe: Dummuqu/Bēl-ahhē-iddin//Egibi, who is the brother-in-law of C2.
 
fA = fNuptāya/Iddin-Marduk//Nūr-Sîn; B = Bēl-ēṭir/Aplāya//Bēl-ēṭiru; C1 = Atkal-ana-Marduk; C2 = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi

elementText.text:
Interim settlement of accounts within the framework of a business partnership (harranu)
A1 and A2 Concerns 50 shekels in cash (hāṭu), 15;0.0.0 kor of dates valued at (ana kaspi manû) 15 shekels of silver, 30 beer barrels valued at 45 shekels of silver, 20 shekels of silver that are due from C, 15 shekels of silver that are at D's disposal, and 5 shekels of silver that are at E's disposal. This total amount of 2 minas and 30 shekels of silver belong to the business partnership of A and B. The part of the silver that is overdue (ina ṣēri nemerkû) B should pay back to the business (ana harrāni nasāku) from his own assets (ultu ramāni), or in other words: not from the profits that he made with it. He is entitled to take (našû) whatever exceeds this (utru). This arrangement does pertain (elat) to a broken amount of silver that is at E's disposal.
 
A = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; B = Kalbāya/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; C = Bēl-apla-iddin/Maštuk; D = Iqīšāya/Ṣillāya; E = Sūqāya/Zababa-zēra-iqīša

elementText.text:
House rental.
A rents a house located in front of (ina pani) the Giššu-Gate to B, for a yearly rental price amounting to 1/3 mina and 3 shekels of silver. The renter should repair the wall foundations (asurrû) and caulk (šanû) the roof. He should also pay for the additional payment (nūptu) in Nisan (I), Dûzu (IV) and Kislim (IX). It is agreed that half of the silver should be paid at the beginning of the year, and the remainder in the middle; the landlord has (already) received 5 shekels of silver as payment for the rent. The house is at the renter’s disposal from the 1st of Ulūl (VI) onwards. The costs for building doors (daltu zaqāpu) inside the house can be credited to A's account. This arrangement comes in addition (elat) to the one concerning  7 1/4 shekels of silver that are at C's disposal (ina pani). Name of 1 witness and the scribe.
 
A = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B = Gimillu/Šāpik-zēri//Bā'iru; C = Šumu-ukīn

elementText.text:
About a silver debt, within the framework of a business partnership.
B owes 2 minas and 7 ½ shekels of medium quality silver, of which one-fifth is alloy (hummušu) and 50 shekels of medium quality silver, of which one-twelfth is alloy (girrētu) (to A, according to BM30874). The present document points out that 1 mina of this silver is what C invested in a business partnership with A (ša harrāni ša ~). Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe: Bēl-ušallim/Zēria//Nabāya.
 
A = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; B = Mušēzib-Marduk/Marduk-ēṭir//Nappāhu; C = Širiktu(/Nūrea//Dannea)

elementText.text:
Purchase of land.
The tablet records the purchase of agricultural land; the text has been divided into paragraphs, marked on the tablet by a line drawn at the end of each one (and indicated below in the paraphrase by LINE).
A purchases land from B. The upper side in the North, 1320 cubits (660 m) long, borders on C, its lower long side in the South which has the same length borders on D. The upper front in the West, 53 1/2 cubits (26,75 m) long, borders on the bank of the Euphrates (kišād Puratti) and the lower front in the East borders on (the property of) A, the buyer. The total measure (mišihtu) of this field is 1;0.3.2 Kor (15000 m2), including the share (zittu) of B, amounting to 0;1.2.1.5 1/2 Kor (3716,5 m2) including 0;0.1 Kor (450 m2) of land between the fields (birat), which he had not yet divided (zu’uzu) with A. LINE
A has declared the equivalent for this land together with the seller B (A itti B mahīra nabû): the land is valued 1 shekel per 1 SILÀ 1 1/4 gar (84,3 m2) – 38 2/3 shekels in total – and the land between the fields (birat) is valued 1 shekel per 4 1/2 SILÀ (337,5 m2) – 1 1/3 shekels in total. A has paid 40 shekels of silver, plus 1 shekel as additional payment (aki atri). LINE
In total, B receives (mahāru) 41 shekels of silver in pieces (šibirtu) from the buyer, the total price (šīmu) for his field. The seller is satisfied (apālu G Stat), and the parties agree that in future times there will be no claims or suits against each other – otherwise, a future claimant (pāqirānu) will have to repay twelvefold the silver he received. Names of 4 witnesses; name of the scribe lost.
 
A = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B = Nergal-zēru-ibni/Nabû-mukīn-zēri//Asû; C = Mušallim-Marduk/Asû; D = Tabnēa/Asû

elementText.text:
Purchase of land;
A purchases a plot of land from B, who shares the property of it with his uncle C. The opening lines, which contained information on the surface area together with its typology and adjacent properties, are lost – except for the mentioning of one neighbour, D, and the indication that it is a measured field (zēru mišihti). Also the rest of the text is poorly preserved. From what can still be read one infers that the seller acknowledges that he has received the full amount of silver corresponding to the purchase price (šīmišu gamrūtu). Names of witnesses and scribe lost. The same purchase is recorded (with more details) in the tablet O637.
 
A = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; B = Nergal-zēru-ibni/Nergal-uballiṭ//Sagdidi; C = Taqīš-Gula, uncle of B; D = Kabtia/Nādin//Suhāya

elementText.text:
Receipt for silver. Purchase price for land.
B receives (ittenṭir, [eṭēru N]) 26 shekels of white silver from A as has been agreed upon (aki ṭuppi). It is the price for land planted with trees (zēru zaqpu) and a plot of land of bad soil quality (kalû u gabību) in Šaḫrīnu which he sold to A on the 5th of Adar (XII) of the previous year (Darius 22). Should the original document or any duplicate of it be found in the seller’s house, this will belong to the buyer. Names of 7 witnesses and scribe.
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; B = Nabû-uballiṭ/Lūṣi-ana-nūri//Andahar

elementText.text:
Establishment of a business partnership (harranu).
A1 and A2 invest 1 mina of silver in a business partnership with B, slave of A2. The parties agree that the investors will have a share in whatever he (= B) makes with(*) the invested silver in or out of town that equals his share. A1 will provide a slave to B who will participate in running the business (našpartu alāku). Names of xxx witnesses and the scribe.
(*)i-šal-li-mu-x, from šalāmu G, instead of usual epēšu.
 
A1 = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; A2 = Šāpik-zēri/Nabû-šumu-iddin//Nādin-še'im; B = Nabû-dīni-epuš, slave of A2

elementText.text:
Security for a silver debt.
B1 (still) owes 2 minas and 14 shekels of silver to A, for which, among others, C's house is given as (after-)pledge (cf. BM30350 = Nbk. 133). Out of the said amount of silver, 1 mina and 54 ½ shekels are (now) owed by B2 his son (lit. are at B2’s disposal, ina pāni) and for the remaining amount (rēhu) the son will pay 2 shekels on a monthly basis in the form of (kima) house rent to A from the 1st of Abu (V) onwards. At the end of the document, after the list of witnesses and the date, and written on the tablet's upper edge, the issue of pledge and house rent is taken up in more detail, but part of the phraseology remains obscure. It is said that the previous house rent due from (ina pāni) B1 and the house rent due from B2 to […] A (uncl.); fD and whatever B1 (lit. "he") owns in and outside of the city are pledged to A. On the same matter, see also its final settlement in BM30348 = Nbk. 172 (2 ½ years after the current document). Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Nergal-uballiṭ/Išum-uballiṭ//Bēl-ēṭiru; B1 = Šulāya/Nabû-zēru-ukīn//Egibi; B2 = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; C= (Marduk-)Šāpik-zēri/Marduk-zēru-ibni//Šangû-Ninurta; fD = fIna-ṣilli-Bēl

elementText.text:
Hiring of a person
A will travel overland (ana ṣēri alāku) with B, the slave of C  for a monthly payment of 2 shekels of silver. They will leave the next day (on the 15th of Ayyar (II)). He should [give} each day x+1200 onion strings as (his) labour obligation (iškaru). The onions … (at this point the tablet breaks off). Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe: Nabû-aplu-iddin/Nabû-mušētiq-uddê//Damqa.
 
A = Mušēzib-Marduk/Marduk-nāṣir; B = Ṣilli-Bēl, slave of C; C = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn

elementText.text:
Settlement of accounts
A and B have settled their accounts (epuš nikkassi qatû) for interest (hubullu) and house rent (idi bīti) for the entire previous year till the 1st of Nisan (I) of Nabonidus’ 4th regnal year. Since the beginning of the year, the house has been at B’s and C’s disposal. Part of the house rent (idū) from (?) the 1st of Nisan (onwards) hase been received (mahāru) from B and C. Names of witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; B = Sūqāya/Kalbāya//Bābūtu; C = Bēl-aplu-iddin

elementText.text:
Sale of slaves.
A, of his own free will, sells his female slave fC1, with her 6 months old baby and C2, her 13 years old son, to B. The text points out that the baby is the son of A's brother. The agreed purchase price amounts to 1 mina and 5 shekels of silver. A guarantees against (suits brought by) a person acting unlawfully (sēhû) or a person claiming (pāqirānu) that fC1 and her sons are palace slave (amat ekalli) or free person (mār banê). Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Bēl-iddin/Silīm-Bēl//Damqa; B = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; fC1 = fHabaṣīrtu; C2 = Bānitu-taddin

elementText.text:
Summon.
On Dûzu (IV), 10th, A1 and A2 will lead B1, and B2 to the entrance of the Crown Prince’s house. C, the clerk (uncertain: the term sēpiru is only partially readable), will settle with them the accounts for the tinned hides (ṣallu) and the dyed leather (dušû). The hides that are then still owed by A1 and A2 they will pay […] as established in C’s parchments (niāru). Names of 2 witnesses. Scribe: Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi.
 
A1 = Marduk-nādin-šumi/Marduk-šarrāni; A2 = Nabû-zēru-ibni/Nabû-tuktû-erība; B1 = Kalbāya/Nabû-tuktû-erība; B2 = Kalbāya/Gabbia; C = Kināya, sēpiru

elementText.text:
About a business partnership? (harranu). Very fragmentary.
The document is in such a bad state of preservation that the type of transaction recorded in it cannot be determined. It seems to be related to a business partnership. Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi, head of the Egibi family is among the protagonists. Names of at least 5 witnesses and the scribe: Itti-Nabû-balāṭu/Marduk-šumu-uṣur//Nappāhu. At the very end of the document a short remark mentions dates of Kalbāya which Bêl-sūpê-muhur brought.

elementText.text:
Appropriation of land instead of dowry-silver from the paternal estate. Promissory note for the remaining dowry-silver.
Concerns 24 minas of silver that belong to fC's dowry and that her husband’s father (A2) received (mahāru) from her father (B) (cf. Wunsch 1993, no. 109). Apparently, A1 had invested the silver in his own business, so that even years later, after his death, his son, A1 takes possession (leqû) of the (i.e. his family’s) arable land at the Zabunu- and Hazuzu-ditches, property (bītu) that had been received (by the family) (mahāru) from D. The land has thus become part of  his wife’s dowry instead (kī) of part of the original 24 minas of dowry-silver. By appropriating it, A1 acted in accordance with what had been agreed between him and his brothers (aki ṭuppišunu, lit. “according to their tablets”). The remaining (dowry-)silver (rīhtu) will be paid from that part of the paternal estate that remains undivided (karû bīt abi). On fC’s dowry, see also BM33114 (= Wunsch 1993, no. 137). Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1= Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; A2 = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi, father of A1; B = Iddin-Marduk(//Nūr-Sîn); fC = fNuptāya/Iddin-Marduk//Nūr-Sîn, wife of A1; D = Tabnēa (without affiliation); E= Iddin-Nabû, brother of A1; F = Nergal-ēṭir, brother of A1

elementText.text:
Promissory note for silver without interest. General pledge.
B owes 33 shekels of silver to A, to be paid without interest in Nisan (I) and pledges all his property in and outside the city. The silver was originally owed by his father. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe: Nabû-napišti-uṣur/Marduk-ēṭir/Ur-Nanna. The third witness is the debtor's mother.

A = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšaya//Nūr-Sîn; B = Nabû-aplu-iddin/Nabû-mušētiq-uddê/Damqa

elementText.text:
Receipt.
Concerning the promissory note (u’iltu) for the total amount of 10 minas of white silver, 71 kor of dates and 13 kor of barley belonging to A that are due from B. Of this total debt A receives (mahāru) from B 71 kor of dates and 13 kor of barley. The parties have each taken a copy of this document. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe: Bēl-uballiṭ//Ir’anni] (= A)
See also the receipts: BM30255 (Dar. 545), MLC 689 (BRM 1 79 // Dar. 539) and the promissory notes: BM30746 (Dar. 507); BM35338 (Dar. 462), BM31578 (Dar. 515).
 
A= Bēl-uballiṭ/Bēl-ēṭir//Ir’anni; B=Širku/Itti-Marduk-Balāṭu//Egibi

elementText.text:
Sale of a slave and settlement of a previous debt.
A, of his own free will, sells his slave C to B, for an agreed purchase price amounting to 1 mina of silver. fD, A’s wife, guarantees against (suits brought by) a person acting unlawfully (sēhû) or a person claiming (pāqirānu) that the slave! (the text has “slaves”) is a palace servant (arad ekalli) or a free person (mār banê). A's debt to B (rāšû ša muhhi A) has been settled (ana eṭēri nadnu) with the silver from the sale. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Nabû-zēru-ukīn/Nabû-šumu-ukīn//Ašlāku; B = Nabû-uṣur-šū/Balāṭu//Miṣirāya; C = Rēmūt-Bāba; fD = fHabaṣīrtu/Bēl-ahhē-iddin, wife of A

elementText.text:
Boat Rental. Fragmentary.
The upper part of the tablet is broken. When the text resumes, one reads that A haspaid an unknown amount of silver through his proxy C, D’s slave. C has unloaded the boat and then handed it  over to E. The boat will be at F’s disposal from the 1st of Abu (V) onward. Names of xxx witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = .../…-ahhē-ušallim; C = Nabû-uterri/uṭerri, slave of D; D = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; E = Šamaš-ēreš; F = Nabû-ēreš

elementText.text:
Receipt
A receives (eṭēru) 30 shekels of silver from B for his urāšu-obligation for the baking (ṣarāpu) of bricks (agurru) from (ultu) Dûzi (IV) of the 1st year of Cambyses for the period of one year (adi ṭuppi ana ṭuppi). His first installment (rēšu) is paid (eṭēru). Each of the partners have taken a copy of the present document. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Bāni-zēri; B = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn

elementText.text:
Purchase of land.
A purchases 0;0.4.1.9 Kor (1942,5 m2) of agricultural land (zēru) located in the open country (eqel ṣēri) from B1 and fB2: it is a cultivated date garden (kirû gišimmarē zaqpi) in front of the Zababa Gate in the district (pīhatu) of Babylon. Its upper side in the West borders on (the property of) A, the buyer, the lower side in the East on (the property f) C; the upper front in the North is adjacent to the bank (kišādu) of the Bitqu-ša-Ile’’i-Bēl and the lower front in the South borders on (the property of) D. A declares the equivalent for this land of 0;0.4.1.9 Kor (1942,5 m2) together with the sellers B1 and his mother fB2 (A itti B mahīra nabû išām) to be 40 shekels of silver as total purchase price (šīmišu gamrūtu) plus 2 shekels of silver as additional payment (kî atri). B1 and fB2 acknowledge that they have received (mahāru) 42 shekels of silver in pieces (šibirtu), and they are satisfied (aplū). The parties agree that in future times there will be no claims or suits against each other, not even between members of their families – otherwise, any future claimant (pāqirānu) will have to repay twelvefold the silver he received. The field will be measured: should it be found larger or smaller than what was originally calculated, they will compensate each other (ahāmiš apālu ) according to the field-price ratio (mahīru) they agreed upon. Fingernails impressions (ṣupru) of the sellers, B1 and his mother fB2, instead of their seal impressions (kunukku). Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B1 = Nādin/Rēmūt//Eppeš-ilī; fB2 = fTašmētu-damqat, mother of B1; C = Mukīn-zēri/Bēl-rēmanni//Gahal; D = Damqia/Niqūdu//Ir’anni

elementText.text:
Purchase of land.
The tablet records the purchase of agricultural land; the text has been divided into paragraphs, marked on the tablet by a line drawn at the end of each one (and indicated below in the paraphrase by LINE).
A purchases land from B; many details about the field are lost since the top part of the tablet is damaged, only some of the bordering properties are extant. Its upper side in the West borders on two fields, but only one of the owners’ name (C) can still be read, and its lower side in the East borders on D’s land; the upper front in the North is adjacent to the royal domain (pīhat šarri) and its lower front in the South borders on the dam of the hanšus (makallû ša hanšānē). LINE
A has declared the equivalent for this land, 23;2.3 Kor (31725 m2) in total, together with the seller B (A itti B mahīra nabû išām): 1 shekel of silver for each 6 gar (45 m2) of date garden (gišimmarē zaqpu) and 1 shekel of silver for each 45 gar (337,5 m2) of cultivated as well as newly cleared land (mērešu u taptû). A has given (nadānu) 19 minas and 8 shekels of silver as total price (šīmišu gamrūtu) of this field, plus 22 shekels of silver as additional payment (kî atri). LINE
B acknowledges that he has received (mahāru) in total 19 minas and 30 shekels of silver in pieces (šibirtu), and he is satisfied (apālu  G Stat). The parties agree that in future times there will be no claims or suits against each other, not even between members of their families – otherwise, any future claimant (pāqirānu) will have to repay twelvefold the silver he received. One final clause establishes that the field will be measured (mašāhu) and (should its area be found smaller or larger than what they had calculated) they will compensate each other (ahāmiš apālu) according to the field-price ratio (mahīru) they agreed upon. Names of 4+ witnesses and 2 scribes. The numbers related to the fields width are given here following Wunsch’s calculations (Wunsch 2000, 8).
 
A = Aplāya/Iqīša-Marduk//Sîn-nādin-šumi; B = Mušēzib-Bēl/Šamaš-unammir//Basia; C = Mušallim-Marduk/…; D = Iqīša-Marduk

elementText.text:
Receipt
A receives payment (eṭēru) from B for C’s urāšu-obligation from (ultu) … (month is broken) of the 7th year of Cambyses till (adi) the end of Arahsamna (VIII). The document is dated in Simān (III). Names of 3 witnesses, including Nabû-iqīša/Šellibi//Atkuppu, the nephew of B, and the scribe.
 
A = Arad-Nabû/Kī-Bēl/Aškāpu; B = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; C = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn

elementText.text:
Undertaking to warrant for sold slaves.
A took away C, slave of fD, from fD (ina qātē abāku), for silver (ana kaspi), i.e. because of her silver debt to him. He then sold the slave to B (ana kaspi nadānu). The purchase price, whose amount is not explicitly mentioned, was paid with silver of which one-sixth is alloy. A guarantees against (suits brought by) a person acting unlawfully (sēhû) or a person raising claims (pāqirānu). Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe: Nabû-ēṭir-napšāti/Nabû-apla-uṣur.
 
A= Nabû-ēṭir-napšāti/Nabû-nā'id/Mandid; B = Kāṣir/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; C = Itti-Nabû-īnia, slave of fD; fD= fGuzummu.

elementText.text:
Undertaking by the guarantor to bring along the debtor
A has a claim against B; C, no doubt the guarantor, undertakes to bring along B on the 20th of Ṭebēt (X) and hand him over to A in Huṣṣētu-ša-Nabû-immê. Should A be absent, C can hand the debtor over to D or pay the debt himself. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe: Aplāya/Šumu-ukīn.
 
A = Šulāya/Šumu-ukīn; B = Nabû-nāṣir/ Mušēzib; C = Šamā’-ilu/ Nabû-ahhu-iddin; D = Mukīn-zēri(/ Marduk-ēṭir//Egibi)

elementText.text:
Warranty for sold slaves by the seller
fA, of her own free will, sold two slaves C1 and her wife  fC2 to B, for a full price (gamru) amounting to 1 1/2 mina. fA guarantees against (suits brought by) a person acting unlawfully (sēhû) or a person claiming (pāqirānu) that the 2 slaves are royal slaves (arad šarrūtu) or free persons (mār banê). Names of witnesses and the scribe.
 
fA = fBēlilitu/Bēl-ušēzib//Ša-nāšišu; B = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; C1 = Nūr-Bēl-lūmur, slave of fA; fC2 = fNanāya-rēmenni, wife of C1 and slave of fA

elementText.text:
Undertaking to deliver barley in exchange for dates.
Concerns the 20 kor of barley that B owes to A in exchange for (šupêltu) dates. B receives (eṭēru) the dates from A and undertakes to deliver the barley according to A’s promissory note by the end of Duzu (IV).
 
A = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; B = Adad-uballiṭ/Nabû-šumu-iddin

elementText.text:
Receipt of silver. Partial payment of a debt.
B owes 6 minas and 16 shekels of silver to A. Of this debt, A receives 5/6 minas of silver.
In addition, there is an earlier promissory note for 2 minas and 51 shekels of silver between the same parties which is still pending. The parties to the contract have taken one copy of the document each. Names of xxx witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Murānu/Nabû-zēru-iddin//Ašlāku; B = Širku(wr. Rikki)/Iddināya//Egibi

elementText.text:
Court protocol.
The tablet is related to C1, the slave of A who bought (ana kaspi mahāru) him from D, however B claims that the slave’s real name is C2 and that he is his slave (qallu), (but) he disappeared (halāqu)". B even swore by the gods: "I really don’t know where he is, he is not with me (ina pānī dagālu)!". Should B know where (the slave) is staying (lit. “where he sees him”), then he should bring him along (abāku) and their case will be discussed (purussû šakānu) in front of the chief judge (sartennu) and the judges (dayyānu). Should this slave be found in D’s house, he will work for 10 days for B as compensation for the time he was absent (mandattu). He will make up for the loss (šalāmu D) according to the royal “law” (akî dātu ša šarri). Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; B = Nabû-aplu-iddin/ Nabunadinahi/ MudammiqMarduk; C1 = Nabû-šepe-šu-šusbat, slave of A; C2 = Nabû-killanni (real name of C1); D = Nabû-uballiṭ/Nabû-aplu-iddin//Sîn-šadûnu

elementText.text:
Allocation of an inheritance share. Very fragmentary.
A receives(?) (The verb is lost in a lacuna) one slave, C3, together with 1/2 mina of silver instead of his fourth-share in the inheritance from B, his elder brother. The slave is one out of a group of six, mentioned in the opening lines: C1 and his wife fC2, together with their son C3 and still nursing (ša šizib) daughter fC4, C5 and fC6: in total 6 slaves (amīlūtu). Rest broken off. Names of 4+ witnesses and the scribe: Itti-Nabû-balāṭu/Marduk-šumu-uṣur//Nappāhu. At the end of the tablet it is pointed out that the text has been written in order to avoid that changes (to the inheritance division) be made (ana lā enê), and that the parties have taken one copy of the document each.
 
A = Nergal-ēṭir/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; C1 =  Uqūpu; fC2 = fSilim-Ištar, wife of C1; C3 = Bēl-pitnanni, son of C1 and fC2; fC4 = fNinlil-rē’ûa, daughter of C1 and fC2; C5 = Ina-qāt-Bēl-šakin; fC6 = fLatubašinni

elementText.text:
Sale of slaves.
B voluntarily sells a family of 5 slaves to A for the hariṣ-price of 2 ½ minas and 5 shekels of silver. The slaves' names are listed below. The seller guarantees that no one will come up with a lawsuit unlawfully (sēḫû) or make a claim (paqirānu) with respect to the slaves; should this happen he will promptly return the purchase price to the buyer. Names of xxx witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Nabû-ahhē-iddin (T: Bēl-ahhē-iddin)/Šulāya//Egibi; B = Šulāya/Ibnāya//Maštuk; C1=Bēl-eṭēri-Nabû; fC2 = fBānītu-rāmat, mother of C1; fC3= fIna-ṣilli-Esabad, sister of C1; fC4 = fRahibā, sister of C1; fC5 = fTašlim, sister of C1.

elementText.text:
Sale of a Slave
A1 and A2, of their own free will, sell their slave C, a baker (nuhattimu), to B for a hariṣ-price amounting to 55 shekels of silver. The sellers guarantee against (suits brought by) a person acting unlawfully (sēhû) or a person claiming (pāqirānu) that C is a royal slave (arad šarrūtu) or a free person (mār banê). Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1 = Nabû-ēreš/Tabnēa/Ahu-bāni; A2 = Nabû-šumu-iškun/Tabnēa/Ahu-bāni; B = Ṭābatu/Lâbāši//Nabāya; C = Nabû-ahu-rēmanni, baker (nuhattimu)

elementText.text:
Promissory oath.
A swears by the gods [names of the gods are broken off] and by king Darius to B that he will certainly bring back at the end of Tašrīt (VII) of Darius’s 24th regnal year the bronze vessel without shoulder(?) (tikkašu iānu) and the bronze PAD-DAR-tu (uncl.) ploughshare (šūrû) which belong to B and that now are at his disposal. He will give them back to their owner before the deadline. Names of xxx witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = ...-Nabû/Nabû-zēru-līšir//Amēl-Ea; B = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi

elementText.text:
Land rental.
A1 rents (ana sūtu nadānu) 1 Kor (13500 m2) of arable land (zēru) located along the Banītu Canal, which he owns together with his brothers and with A2, for 2 years to B (C’s slave). The fixed rent (sūtu) is 2 kor (360 l) of barley (uṭṭatu) per year. The renter will pay this rent to A1 and A2, in addition to (elat) 7 kor (1260 l) of barley (uṭṭatu) for the rent (sūtu) of 3 kor (40500 m2) of land at B’s disposal – as established in a previous promissory note (u’iltu, for which see BM31524). The land will be at the renter’s disposal for 6 years. The parties to the contract have taken one copy of the document each. Names of 6 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1= Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; A2= Bēlet-ēreš/Šamaš-uballiṭ; B= Sîn-ibni; C= Mardukāya

elementText.text:
Deposition before the freemen about an assault between a slave of the Egibi family wearing a ṣibtu-garment and his former business partner.
The document lists the names of 8 freemen (mār-banê) including Šamaš-ah-iddin/Ṭāb-šar-Bēl, the one in charge of the fodder (ša muhhi kissati) and Rīmut, the agricultural supervisor (gugallu) of the Nabû temple. In their presence (ina pāni) A, slave (qallu) of C, declared that B beat him up (ṭēru) in the afternoon (muṣlalu) of the 6th day of Tašrīt (VII) in an unlawful way (šigiltu), pierced (šaqāru D) his ṣibtu-garment with the sharp side of his door-key (sikkat namzaq bābi, wr. gišNĺG.GAG ká) saying as follows: "This is the word (amātu) of the king: a slave doesn’t put on (nadû) a loin cloth (qablu ṣubātu) of first quality (rēštu) wool (šipātu) around his waist (qablu)." The document is dated but there is no list of witnesses (mukinnu). The scribe is Nidinti-Bēl/Iddināya//Sagilāya.
 
A = Madān-bēlu-uṣur; B = Nabû-ēṭir/Nergal-šumu-ibni//Ēṭiru; C = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Šulāya//Egibi
