elementText.text:
Receipt for silver. Final payment of a debt. Return of all promissory notes to the debtor(s).
Concerns the old debt (u'iltu arkītu) for 3 minas of silver that B1 owed to A and for which a promissory note had been issued (e’ēlu). A received payment (eṭēru) for this debt, so that there are no more claims (rašūtu) by A against either B1 or his father B2, be it for silver, barley,  dates or anything else. Whatever promissory note that may still exist (mala bašû) against them, should it turn up (elû) in the creditor's house, it shall belong to the B1. Names of 4 witnesses (3 listed before the date, and one after it), and the scribe. 
 
A=Nabû-neb-ana-ilī/Bābu-iddin//Arrabtu; B1= Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; B2 = Šulāya/Nabû-zēru-ukīn//Egibi, father of B1

elementText.text:
List of silver sums that are available to high officials.
1/2 mina of earlier silver (kaspu mahrû), 1 1/3 minas and 5 shekels of later silver (urkû): in total, 1 mina and 55 shekels of silver at the disposal of (ina pāni) the governor of Nippur (šandabakku), including (ina libbi) the 55 shekels of A, and in addition also (elat) 1 mina of silver that A paid (nadānu, G Stat) for sesame. In the presence of (ina uzuzzi)  D1, D2, D3.
1 mina and 1 shekel at the disposal of B. In the presence of D1, D4 […].
1/2 mina of silver at the disposal of C. In the presence of  […] of Dūr-šarrukku, the bishop (šatammu) of Kiš and the chief priest (šangû) of Dēr. The text may be assigned to the Egibi Archive on the basis of its museum number.
 
A = Nabû-mukīn-zēri (without affiliation); B = Bēl-…; C = broken name; D1 = Nabû-mukīn-zēri/Nergal-ušēzib//Rab-banê; D2 = Šākin-šumi/Nabû-mukīn-apli//Bān-ilī; D3 = Tabnēa/Nabû-šumu-ukīn//Nubû; D4 = Arad-…

elementText.text:
House rental. Very fragmentary.
A1, fA2 and fA3 rent fC’s house, which is near D’s house, to B for 2 years, at a yearly rent amounting to 12 shekels of silver. The text is very damaged, only a few words can be recognised: they must have referred to the agreement of paying half of the silver at the beginning of the year, and the remainder in the middle. Then, the renter’s obligations were mentioned. The house is at the renter’s disposal starting from Simān (III) onwards. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1 = Nabû-ēreš/Bēl-ile’’i//Ṣāhit-ginê; fA2 = fBānītu-ēṭirat/Marduk-šumu-uṣur//Ṣāhit-ginê; fA3 = fAndi-Nanāya/Marduk-šumu-uṣur//Ṣāhit-ginê; B = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; fC = fSîn-bannāya; D = Šumu-iddin/…

elementText.text:
Sale of slaves.
A, of his own free will, sells his female slaves fC1, fC2, and fC3 to B for a total price amounting to 2 2/3 minas of silver. One of the slaves, fC3, is an unweaned infant (ēniqu) and fC2’s daughter. A guarantees against (suits brought by) a person acting unlawfully (sēhû) or a person claiming (pāqirānu) that these female slaves are free persons (mār banê). The seller acknowledges that he has received (eṭēru) the total purchase price from B. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Habaṣīru/Niqūdu; B = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; fC1 = fMiṣatu; fC2 = fNanāya-bēlu-uṣur; fC3 = fŠēpit-Ninlil-aṣbat

elementText.text:
Purchase of land.
A purchases 1;1.4 kor (18000 m2) of agricultural land (zēru), a grain field (pî šulpu) in Šuppatu, from B: part of it, 1 Kor (13500 m2), is cultivated land (mērešu) and the remaining 0;1.4 Kor (4500 m2) is land of bad soil quality (kalû u gabību). This field is the share (zitti) of B, who owns it together with his brothers C1 and C2 and his uncle C3; the description of the plot of land is minimal, only the boundaries for its upper and lower sides are given, i.e.  D’ and E’s properties, but we do not know if they refer to the long side or the front.
A declares the equivalent for this field together with the seller B (itti B A mahīra nabû išām), who acknowledges that he has received (mahāru) an amount of silver in pieces (šibirtu) which is lost in a lacuna, and is (apālu  G Stat). The parties agree that in future times there will be no claims or suits against each other, not even between members of their families – otherwise, any future claimant (pāqirānu) will have to repay twelvefold the silver he received. Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Kidin-Marduk/Zēria//Šangû-Gula; B = Iddin-Marduk/Nabû-mukīn-zēri//Asû; C1 = Nabû-uballiṭ; C2 = Nergal-zēru-ibni; C3 = Mukīn-Marduk; D = Marduk-šumu-ibni/…//Basia; E = Tabnēa/Ina-tēšê-ēṭir//Asû

elementText.text:
Promissory note for silver
B owes 6 shekels of medium quality silver, of which one-eighth is alloy to A, to be paid back in Arahsamna (VIII).
 
A = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; B = Kabtia/Mušallim-Marduk//Bēl-ēṭir

elementText.text:
Receipt for the purchase price of land. Dissolution of a business partnership.
A sold arable land (zēru) situated along the old Kutha Channel to B and acknowledges his receipt (eṭēru) of the corresponding price (the exact amount that is paid is not specified). With this transaction, they agree that all accounts have been settled and consider their former business partnership (harrānu) closed. It is further pointed out that the seller has returned the promissory note (u‘iltu) for payment of the remaining price of the land (târu D – nadānu); and that the buyer gave on his own initiative (ina migir libbīšu) 6 shekels of silver as a gift (qīštu) to the seller. The parties to the contract have taken one  copy of the document each. Names of 10 witnesses and the scribe. The promissory note mentioned in this text must be BM30898 (= Dar 61)
 
A = Bel-ēṭir/Mušēbši//Nūr-Sîn; B = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi.

elementText.text:
Fragmentary. Cannot be classified.
The tablet is too damaged to reconstruct its content. It belongs to the Egibi/Nūr-Sîn archive because Iddin-[Marduk/Iqišāya]//Nūr-Sîn is mentioned. Legible is the word anāku, which may refer to oath taking and the verb inamdin which suggest an undertaking to pay. Apart from the first witness, the names of the witnesses and the scribe are broken.

elementText.text:
Establishment of a business partnership (harranu).
A1 and A2 invest 2/3 minas of silver in a business partnership with fB. The partners agree that they will share equally in whatever fB makes with the silver, so that each one receives one third. The capital sum of the silver is guaranteed by … (at this point the text is badly preserved). Names of xxx witnesses and the scribe.      
 
A1 = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; A2 = Šāpik-zēri/Nabû-šumu-iddin//Nādin-še'im; fB = fNuptaia/Marduk-bēl-ilāni

elementText.text:
Receipt for silver. Related to the "bathhouse".
It concerns a writing board (lē'û, wr. gišDA) of (ša) the (series? / ritual?) Bīt-Rimki; or: a writing board pertaining to the bathhouse (bīt rimki). A sold it for 2 kor of barley to B. The present document records the seller's receipt (eṭēru) of the barley from the buyer. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe: Iqīša/Bunānu//Rab-banê (= seller). 
 
A = Iqīša/Bunānu//Rab-banê; B = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/ Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi

elementText.text:
Addendum to a dowry gift.
fA gives of her own free will 4 mina of silver as dowry for her granddaughter fC to B. Her gift comes in addition to (elat) the … and 3 slaves which she gave in the past according to earlier documents, and the dowry which D (fC’s father) gave. B, the groom acknowledges his receipt of the 4 minas from the bride’s grandmother. Each of the parties has taken one copy of the present document. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe: Itti-Nabû-balāṭu/Marduk-bāni-zēri/Bēl-ēṭiru.

fA= fIna-Esagila-ramât/Zēria/Nabāya, grandmother of C; B=Kurbanni-Marduk/Etellu//Ēṭiru, the groom; fC= fNanāya-ēṭirat/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi, bride and granddaughter of fA; D=Itti-Marduk-balāṭu, father of the bride.

elementText.text:
Sale of slaves.
The two brothers A1 and A2, together with their mother fA3, sell of their own free will four slaves C1, fC2, fC3 and her sister! (the tablet has “wife”) fC4 to B for 2 minas of silver. The sellers guarantee against (suits brought by) a person acting unlawfully (sēhû) or a person claiming (pāqirānu) that these slaves are free persons (mār banê). They guarantee for each other. Names of 6 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1 = Bēl-ahhē-iddin/Esagila-šumu-ibni//Sîn-damāqu; A2 = Nabû-ahhē-bulliṭ/Esagila-šumu-ibni//Sîn-damāqu; und fA3 = fRēšat/Šūzubu//Šangû-parakki, mother of A1 and A2; B = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; C1 = Nabû-edu-uṣur; fC2 = fBānitu-ummu, wife of C1; fC3 = fKišrinni; fC4 = fGimilinni, sister of fC3

elementText.text:
Agreement about repair-works at a house.
The tablet is related to a wall (igāru) of a house that is located in front of the Giššu Gate and belongs to A and his brothers. B has fixed (ṣabātu) its beams (gušūru): now, he will have to remove (dekû) the beams from A’s wall. He should also fill up (malû D) the city's earthen ramp (kamru) which he had breached (abāku Gt) and give it to A. The wall belongs (exclusively) to A: B has no (claim to its) drainpipes (naṣṣabu, wr. x(NIN)->ṣa-bi) (and) beams (or: the za-bi (uncl., perhaps "compensation(?)") of the beams). Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; B = Zababa-iddin/Bēl-iddin//Adad-šamê

elementText.text:
Receipt of payment; purchase of residential estate.
A1 and his mother fA2 sell their built-on plot (bīt epšu) located at the Nabû Gate in Šahrīnu, measuring 9 sq. r (c. 110,25 m2), to B. Details for the localization of this plot are provided: its upper long side in the East borders on B’s (the buyer’s) house, the upper front in the North is adjacent to the wide street (sūqu rapšu) and the lower front in the South borders on C’s house. In a fragmentary passage, the purchase price is calculated at a ratio of 2/3 minas and 8 shekels per each sq. r (12,25 m2) of land and accordingly fixed at 7 minas and 15 shekels of silver. To this a supplementary payment (atru) of [9?] shekels of silver is added. A1 and his mother fA2 acknowledge that they have received in total 7 1/3 minas and 4 shekels (i.e. 7 minas and 24 shekels) of silver from B, as a consequence of the sale of their plot (bītu). The area will be measured: should it be found larger or smaller than what was originally calculated, they will compensate each other according to the field-price ratio they agreed upon. Names of 9 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1 = Nabû-bēlu-kalamu/Nabû-ēṭir-napšāti//La-kubburu; fA2 = fInbāya/Nabû-mukīn-apli//Šigûa, mother of A1; B = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; C = Nabû-mukīn-zēri/Ina-tēšê-ēṭir//Šamaš-abārī

elementText.text:
Promissory note for barley without interest. Business assets(?).
B1 and B2 owe the principal amount of 20 kor of barley to A. A and C, who own each a share in this income, will take (našû) the barley from before (ultu pāni) the debtors, and divide it equally between them (ahata šunu). A is entitled (uzuzzu) to (ina) whatever large (arāku D) or small (karû D) amounts C will obtain from B1 and B2. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Iddin-Marduk/Aplāya; B1 = Hahhuru/Nadnāya; B2 = Būnānu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin; C = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi

elementText.text:
Rental agreement.
A rents land planted with trees (zēru zaqpu), located along the bank (kišādu) of the Banītu-Canal, to B, C’s slave. The land belongs to A and his brother and it includes D’s half share (ahi zitti). It is located near (the land belonging to) E1 and E2, and near F’s sons and E2. The yearly fixed rent (sūtu), valid for 5 years, is established as follows: 38 Kor (6840 l) of dates, 38 loads of firewood (ḫuṣabu), 38 palm-leaf baskets (tuhallu), 38 date baskets (gipû), fibres (mangagu) and 60 darīku-vessels. The tenant will hoe (herû) the ground with a shovel (ina marri) throughout the year. He will also keep something (uncl., wr. šá maš šib tú) in good order, and dig (aṣû Š) a lower drainage canal (āṣītu) from the river bank (kišādu) to the lower bank (šēpu) of the upper canal. The parties to the contract have taken one copy of the document each. Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; B = Sîn-ibni, C’s slave; C = Mardukāya; D = Bēlet-ēreš/Šamaš-uballiṭ; E1 = Bēl-erība/Pir’u; E2 = Iddin-Nabû/ Zuzia; F = Nabû-šarrui-bni

elementText.text:
Hiring of a slave. To do repair work
A leases his slave C who is a leatherworker to B for 3¼ shekels of silver. He has to do repair work on the house and in return he will receive clothing (muṣiptu) from B. The latter also has to provide for the kīnayātu-gifts for the Enlil(-ceremony) in Nisan as an additional payment (nuptu). During one year (adi ṭuppi ṭuppi) will the slave be at his disposal(?). Names of xxx witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B = Iddin-Bēl/Silim-Bēl//…; C = Nabû-ku-ú..., slave.

elementText.text:
Receipt
A receives (mahāru) 4 shekels of silver from fB1, wife of B2, a tax payment to finance work (dullu) at the Ninlil canal (nāru). Apart from the names of 3 ina uzuzzi witnesses, no place or scribe are mentioned. 
 
A = Nūrea/Šāpik-zēri; fB1 =  fIna-Esagila-rāmat/Zēria//Nabāya; B2 = Iddin-Marduk(/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn)

elementText.text:
Division of commonly held land between family members.
Record of a division of shares (ṭuppi zitti) in land located above and below the New Canal in front of (mihrat) the Enlil Gate in the district (pīḫatu) of Babylon and planted partly with trees (zēru zaqpu) and partly of grain (merēšu). A and B, his paternal uncle, divide it between them (itti ahameš zâzu) – A having included also his brothers' share.
For the purpose of describing the two shares in the land, which cover irregular surfaces, they have been divided into smaller portions. The document begins with B’s share. The first measured area (mišihtu) consists of 1;1.5.3.8 kor (18735 m2) of arable land (zēru) including 4 gar (30 m2) of a triangular shaped plot and the land between the fields (adi birat). The upper long side in the West measures 988 1/3 cubits (c. 494,1 m), is adjacent to the 4 gar (30 m2) of triangular shaped land that is an integral part of the measured area (santakki libbi eqli), and borders on (the properties of) C1 and C2; the lower long side in the East is 1006 5/6 cubits (c. 503,4 m) long and borders on the share taken (ṣabātu) by A. The upper front in the North measures 76 1/6 cubits (c. 38,08 m), includes 2 1/2 cubits (1,25 m), the short side of the triangular shaped land (pūt santakki), and is adjacent to the bank (kišādu) of the New Canal; the lower front in the South is adjacent to the next portion of land.
The second measured area (mišihtu) consists of 3;3.3.4.7 kor (50302,5 m2) of arable land (zēru), including aškuttu-land. Its upper long side in the West is 2643 cubits (1321,5 m) long and borders on (the property of) D, the oblate (širku) of Marduk, the lower side in the East measures 2646 cubits (1323 m) and borders on (the property of) A. The upper front in the North measures 78 cubits (39 m) and is adjacent to the first area; the lower front in the South measures 86 1/2 cubits (23,25 m) and is adjacent to the aškuttu-land of this field.
The third measured area (mišihtu) consists of 1;0.2.4.2 kor (14715 m2) of arable land (zēru), of which 0;1.5.5 kor (5325 m2) is cultivated land (mērešu). Its upper long side in the West is 858 cubits (4279 m) long and borders on (the property of) D, the oblate (širku) of Marduk, the lower side in the East measures 855 cubits (427,5 m) and borders on (the property of) A. The upper front in the North measures 65 cubits (32,5 m) and is adjacent to the dam of the hanšû (makallû ša hanšānē); the lower front in the South measures 75 1/2 cubits (32,75 m) and is adjacent to the bank (kišādu) of the New Canal. The total share taken by B, A’s uncle, consists of 6;1.0.0.7 Kor (83752,5 m2) of land cultivated with trees and grain (zēru zaqpu u mērešu).
Then, the text gives details for A’s share. The first measured area (mišihtu) consists of 1;2.1.5.5 Kor (19762,5 m2) of arable land (zēru). Its upper long side in the West measures 1006 5/6 cubits (503,41 m) and borders on the share that B took (ṣabātu); the lower long side in the East is 1025 cubits (512,5 m) long and borders on (the property of fE. The upper front in the North measures 76 1/3 cubits (38,16 m) and is adjacent to the bank (kišādu) of the New Canal; the lower front in the South is 79 1/3 cubits (39,66m) long and is adjacent to the next portion of land.
The second measured area (mišihtu) consists of 3;3.3.5.3 kor (50347,5 m2) of arable land (zēru), including aškuttu-land. Its upper long side in the West measures 2646 1/2 cubits (1323,25 m) and borders on B’s share; the lower long side in the South is 2650 (1325 m) long and borders on (the property of) fE. The upper front in the North is 78 cubits (39 m) long and is adjacent to the next portion of land, the lower front in the South measures 85 cubits (42,5 m) and is adjacent to 0;0.2.5.5 Kor (1312,5 m2) of  aškuttu-land that is part of this portion.
The third measured area (mišihtu) consists of 1;0.2.3.6 kor (14760 m2) of arable land (zēru), of which 0;1.5.5 kor (5325 m2) is cultivated land (mērešu). The upper long side in the West is 855 cubits (427,5 m) long and borders on the land taken by B; the lower long side in the East measures 852 cubits (426 m) and borders on (the property of) fE. The upper front in the North measures 65 cubits (32,5 m) and is adjacent to the dam of the hanšû (makallû ša hanšānē); the lower front in the South measures 75 1/2 cubits (32,75 m) and is adjacent to the bank (kišādu) of the New Canal.
The total share taken by A, including his brother’s share, consists of 6.[…] Kor (81000+ m2) of land cultivated with trees and grain (zēru zaqpu u mērešu).
A and B take (ṣabātu) each one his share; they promise that they will not withhold (kalû) water nor access to the land (mû u muṣû) to each other. They have taken (leqû) one copy of the document each. Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe.
BM30627 provides a detailed plan of the shared land.
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; B = Nergal-ēṭir, uncle of A; C1 = Tabnēa/Nabû-aplu-iddin; C2 = Nabû-tabni-uṣur/Rēmūt; D = Nabû-uballiṭ, oblate (širku) of Marduk/Kuššāya; fE = fBarsippītu/Arad-Marduk//Ile''i-Marduk

elementText.text:
Leasing of a slave or work contract: copy of a previous, fragmentary document.
This fragment of a tablet consists in a copy of a previous document, which was already in poor condition in antiquity: the scribe, in fact, indicates with the usual indication hepi the several gaps he found in the original tablet. A, baker (nuhatimmu) and B’s slave,  <broken> will perform (epēšu) the craft of the baker (nuhatimmūtu) with <broken> C, D’s slave. <broken>  He will deliver (nadānu) every day 30 loaves of bread, from an unknown day of Šabāṭ (XI) until <broken>. From the end of Addar (XII) to […] (broken off, large gap). In the final readable lines, it is stated that C will give (nadānu) the compensatory payment (mandattu) to B. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe: Bēl-kāṣir/Rehētu/Isināya.
 
A = broken name, baker and slave of B; B = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; C = ...-ṣābit-qātia, slave of D; D = Iqīša-Marduk/Dābibi

elementText.text:
Purchase of livestock. Fragmentary.
A sells (lit. “gives”, nadānu) 2 free-roaming cows (sāhirtu), that […], 20 female (nursing) goats (enzu mūnīqu) […] and 20 young male goats (enzu gadû) […] to B for 1 mina and 32 shekels of silver. The seller guarantees against prior claims (uškûtu) related to this livestock. A deducts (elû Š) the silver for the goats from (the amount due by) C1 and C2. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe: Marduk-rēmanni/Nabû-….
 
A = Rēmūtu/Nabû-rīhtu-uṣur; B = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; C1 = Kināya; C2 = Guzia

Concerning the 0;0.2.2 kor of land (zēru) which A1 and A2 sold to B (cf. BM 30449 and RM 942). A1 and A2 receive (mahāru) in sum (napharu) 8 5/12 shekels of silver from B. A1 = Nabû-ēreš; A2 = Šāpik-zēri/Šumu-ukīn//Sîn-šadûnu; B = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi

elementText.text:
Gift by a husband to his wife in lieu of dowry items.
A, of his own free will, issues a sealed document in which he gives (kanāku – dagālu D) real estate and slaves to his wife  fB in compensation for the dowry items that he had either sold or incorporated in his own assets. Thus, he gives her his share in a plot of land cultivated with trees and grain that he owns together with his brothers and that is located in Bīt-kāṣir(?) on the Ṭupāšu-Canal, as well as 8 slaves: C1, his wife fC2, her 5 children ( D1, D2, D3, D4,fD5), and fE.  All this is given in lieu of (kum) the following dowry items: 30 minas of white silver, 2 minas of gold, 5 minas of silver (in the form of) coils (qullu), 10 bracelets (semeru), and the two slaves (F1 and fF2) whom A had sold. Names of xxx witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; fB = fAmat-Bāba/Kalbāya//Nabāya; C1 = Madān-bēlu-uṣur; fC2 = fNanāya-bēlu-uṣur; D1 = Zababa-iddin, son of fC2; D2 = Madānu-iddin, son of fC2; D3 = Bēlū-gabbi-Bēlumma, son of fB2; D4 = Ahušunu, son of fC2; fD5 = Hašdāya, daughter of fC2; fE = fKaṣīrtu; F1 = Nabû-ittia, slave; fF2 = fNanāya-kilīlī-uṣrī, slave

elementText.text:
Promissory note for barley. Very fragmentary.
The top part of the tablet is lost. From what is extant, one understands that A owes to B, C’s slave, [x]+0;0.4 kor (c. 24 l) of barley. The debtor will pay the full amount according to C's measure (mašīhu) in one instalment (ina muhhi ištet ritti) in C's house. Delivery is due in a month whose name is lost in a lacuna. Rest broken off. Names of witnesses and scribe broken off.
 
A = …/Rēmūt; B = Madān-bēlu-uṣur; C = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi

elementText.text:
Sale of two slaves. Fragmentary.
A1 and A2 together with their mother fA3, out of their own free will, sell fC1 and her daughter fC2 to B, for their entire value (šīmu gamru). These sold persons, no doubt slaves but not explicitly labelled as such, derive from a previous exchange that the sellers made (šupêlu) with D for a house in Borsippa. Names of 1+ witnesses and the scribe: Nabû-uballiṭ/Marduk-šumu-uṣur//Nappāhu.
 
A1 = Nabû-ēṭir-napšāti/Šulāya/Nūr-Papsukkal; A2 = Bēl-iddin/Šulāya//Nūr-Papsukkal; fA3 = fInṣabtu/Marduk-zēru-ibni//Ur-Nanna; B = Kalbāya /[...]; fC1 = fMiṣātu; fC2 = fNanāya-bēlu-uṣur; D = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi

elementText.text:

B owes a broken amount of onions to A, to be delivered in Ālu-ša-Ahu-iddin at the Borsippa Canal.
The debt results from a loan of silver to pay for the ṣāb šarri-service obligation. Names of xxx witnesses and the scribe.

elementText.text:
Sale of real estate and receipt of purchase price. Fragmentary.
A sells part of a royal passageway(?) ([bīt(?)] ta-ri-ku-ut-ta) belonging to fC1 and fC2, located near the way out (mūṣû) of his own house, to B: the long side of the purchased passageway measures 7 1/2 cubits (c. 3,75 m), and its short side in the West is adjacent to the way out (mūṣû) of B’s house. The purchase price amounts to 15 shekels of white silver (kaspu peṣû): the seller acknowledges that he has received it in full from B. Some of the description of the side is unclear and needs further clarification. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe: Marduk-mukīn-apli/Ibnāya//Rab-līmu.
 
A = Nabû-nāṣir/Itti-Bēl-lummir(?)//Basia; B = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; fC1 = fNuptāya/Nādinu/Bīnāya; fC2 = fAplatu (Achemenet: Abbatu)/Nādinu//Bīnāya, sister of fC1

elementText.text:
Sale of a slave.
A1 and his wife fA2 sold their slave C (part of fA2’s dowry) to B1 and his wife fB2. Now, B1 and fB2 sell this same slave to D, a courtier (rēš šarri), for a purchase price amounting to 1/3 mina and 5 shekels of silver. Then, the text mentions A1 and fA2 again, but the verb of this sentence is broken: from what follows it seems they haven't received their silver yet. At the end of the tablet it is stated that B1 and fB2 (eventually) pay them the 1/3 mina and 5 shekels of silver through the proxy E. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1 = Etel-pî/Ṣillāya//Nubu; fA2 = fHanašu, wife of A1; B1 = Nergal-uballiṭ/Kudurru; fB2 = fHibtāya/Anni-šunu, wife of B1; C = Silīm-Bēl; D = Nabû-ṣābit-qāti, rēš šarri; E = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi

elementText.text:
Sale of slaves.
Seller pays off debts to the temple. A, of his own free will, sells fC1, fC2 and fC3, 3 female slaves (amēluttu), to B for a total purchase price amounting to 3 minas of silver. Part of the price, namely 2 minas and 5 shekels of silver, has been paid to D, the overseer of the herd (rab būli) of (the temple of) Bēl, who will then give (the silver) to the Esagila, in order to cover what remained of the seller's debt (kūm rēhu) in small livestock (ṣēnu) to the temple. The seller guarantees against (suits brought by) a person acting unlawfully (sēhû) or a person raising claims (pāqirānu) over fC1, fC2 and fC3. Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe: Bēl-erība/Ahūšunu.
 
A = Madān-šuma-iddin/Nergal-zēra-ibni; B = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; fC1 = fUmma-ana-āli; fC2 = fGudādîtu; fC3 = fRē'indu; D = Madān-iqīša, overseer of the Esagila's herd (rab būli of Bēl)

elementText.text:
Court protocol.
The tablet records an accusatory deposition in court and the royal judges' decision. The plaintiffs are fA1 and her adopted son A2; the defendant is her husband's brother B. The case primarily concerns her rights to a house that she and her husband bought with her dowry silver.
The court protocol opens with a quotation of fA1's statement before the judges of Nabonidus. She recounts that she is married to A3, brought 3 1/2 minas of silver as her dowry (nudunnû) into the marriage, and bore him a daughter fD. Together they bought a built house (bītu epšu), 8 reeds (c. 90 m2) large, in the district (erṣetu) called “Small region on the other bank” (ahullā qalla) in Borsippa, for 9 minas and 20 shekels of silver. The purchase was financed a.o. with her dowry silver and with a loan (ana nishi našû) of 2 minas and 30 shekels of silver from C (cf. BM30506 = Nbn 187). In Nabonidus’ 4th regnal year, she argued with her husband (itti ragāmu) about (aššu) her dowry and he, with full consent (ina migir libbišu), gave her under seal (kanāku - dagālu Š) that built house in Borsippa, forever (ana ūmī ṣâti). In the donation document, he stated that they agreed to pay off together (itti ahameš eṭēru) the 2 1/2 minas of silver that they borrowed (našû) from B for the purchase of that house. A3 wrote down (šaṭāru) the oath that he pronounced by the great gods in the document and sealed it. In Nabonidus’ 5th regnal year, she and her husband adopted C as son (ana mārūti leqû), and they wrote (šaṭāru) an adoption tablet (ṭuppi mārūti) for him. At that time they also made known (idû Š) the content of their daughter's dowry (fD): 2 minas and 10 shekels of silver and household goods (udê bīti). Now, after A3’s death, B, his brother (= fA1's in-law, emû) has raised a claim (paqāri bašû Š) on the house and on everything else that his brother gave to fA1 in a sealed document (kanāku – dagālu Š), as well as on a slave, E, whom the couple bought (ana kaspi abāku) from F. fA1 concludes her statement by saying: I have brought (abālu) him in front of you: establish our decision (purussû šakānu)!”.
The second part of the tablet records the judges’ actions and verdict. They hear the parties’ arguments (dibbu šemû), review (šasû) the tablets (ṭuppu) and contracts (riksu) that fA1 brought as evidence, and deliberate (mitluku). They deny B’s claims (la rašû Š) on the house in Borsippa, which had been given to fA1 instead of her dowry (kūm nudunnê), the slave E whom she bought (ana kaspi šâmu) together with her husband and everything else that belonged to A3. The judges establish the legal rights of  fA1 and A2 on the basis of their written evidence (ina ṭuppi uzuzzu). B will have priority (penû) in recovering (šalāmu G) the silver, 2 1/2 minas, which was used to pay for the house; then, fA1 will recover  the 3 1/2 minas of silver from her dowry; finally, fD will get E as her inheritance share (zittu), as established in her father’s contracts (riksu). Names of 6 witnesses, all judges of Nabonidus, and 2 scribes: Nādin//Pahāru, and Nabû-šumu-iškun//Rab-bānê. Seal impression of the judges.
 
fA1 = fBunanītu/Hariṣāya, wife of A3; A2 = Apla-dādu-abārī, adopted son of fA1 and A3; A3 = Apla-dād-natan/Niqmadu; B = Aqab-ili, fA1's in-law (emû); C = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; fD = fNuptāya, daughter of fA1 and A3; E = Nabû-nūr-ilī; F = Nabû-ahhē-iddin

elementText.text:
Land rental.
A rents 0;2 Kor (5400 m2) of arable land (zēru) located along his irrigation canal (namgaru) and within C’s field to B, who should perform gardening work (nukaribbūtu). He will take care of the palm fronds (libbu) and branches (harūtu); in Abu (V), he should carry out the excavation work for irrigation. He will irrigate the field drawing water from the previous canal. Name of 1 witness and the scribe.
 
A = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B = Sîn-abu-uṣur/Addu-rahî; C = Mušēzib-Bēl/Nabû-ēreš//Šangû-Nabû

elementText.text:
About the ownership over (confiscated) slaves
A took away (abāku) two slaves (amīlūtu), C1 and his wife fC2, from fB1, for (an unpaid debt of) silver (ana kaspi)(*), but fB1’s son, B2 lodged a claim of prior encumbrances(?)(sa-ku-ú-tu paqāru, D) and led them away (abāku). It is decided that  B2, not A, is to be considered the holder of prior claims (uškû).  Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe: Mušallim-Marduk/Iqīša-Marduk/Sîn-nāṣir.
Notes: (*)Alternatively, ana kaspi abāku = “to buy”.
 
A= Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; fB1= fBēlilitu/Bēl-ušēzib, mother of B2; B2= Zēria/Balāssu//Dannēa; C1=Nūr-Bēl-lūmur, slave; fC2= fNanāya-rēminni, slave, wife of C1

elementText.text:
Sale of slaves
A, of his own free will, sells C1 and his wife fC2, together with their 5 years old daughter fC3, (3 slaves in total) to B for an agreed purchase price amounting to 2 minas of silver. The seller guarantees against (suits brought by) a person acting unlawfully (sēhû) or a person claiming (pāqirānu) that these slaves are palace servants (arad ekalli) or free persons (mār banê). Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Nabû-ēreš/Tabnēa//Ahu-bāni; B = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; C1 = Lūmur-dumqi-Bēl; fC2 = fSinun(t)u, wife of C1; fC3 = fIna-Bāba-magāri-alsīš(?), daughter of C1 and fC2

elementText.text:
Promissory oath. Undertaking to settle a dispute.
A, the gardener swears (tamû) to B before Bēl, Nabû and king Darius and in the presence (ina pāni) of the freemen (mār-banê) that he will come (alāku) by the 8th of Šabāṭ (XI), argue his case (wr. dib!-⌈bi x ⌉-ma, =? dibbu dabābu), and end (the dispute) (qatû). Names of 5 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Iqūpu; B = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi

Sale of a slave.
A, of his own free will, sells his slave C to B. The agreed purchase price amounts to 5/6 mina and 8 shekels of silver. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Kudurru/Iqīša; B = Šulāya/Nabû-zēru-ukīn//Egibi; C = Nabû-rīhtu-uṣur

elementText.text: The document is too fragmentary in order to determine its exact content. It seems to be related to the sale of a field. At the beginning we can see remnants of personal names, a.o. the person who owns land next to the seller (maḫirānu) of a field (eqlu), followed by a description of the field’s location, and the remnants of a sale formula (mahīru nabû, ana šīmi). At the sealing of this document were present at least 10 witnesses. Present (ina ašābi) was further fBēlilitu, wife of Arad-Ninurta-mi-tu. Name of the scribe is probably Nabû-šumu-uṣur/Šulāya//Egibi (l. 22f.). A final note points out that silver for going on a campaign (ana alāki ša madakti) …. Arad-Ninurta-mi-tu has been given (nadnu).

elementText.text:
House rental.
A rents a house located at the head (qaqqadu) of the bridge (gišru) in Borsippa to B, for a yearly rental price amounting to 1/2 mina and 5 shekels of silver. B will pay the rent for this house to the landlord this month (ITI-àm). A short remark at the very end of the document (after the list of witnesses and the date) seems to pick this issue up again by pointing out that "till(?) ([a]-di) the 2nd of Iyyar (II), i.e. the day of recording this document, the rent has (or has not yet) been paid: there is no verb. The passage may need to be collated. The renter should caulk (šanû) the roof and repair the wall foundations (asurrû). A will be charged (manû) for whatever work (dullu) that is to be done inside it with bricks (libnāte), reeds (qanâte) and beams (gušūri). The renter should also deliver 0;0.2 kor (2 l.) of tābīlu-herbs each year. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B = Kināya/Lamassanni-Gula//Šangû-Gula

elementText.text:
Measurement of plots of land.
The tablet records the result of the measurement of a large plot of land, about 1225 km long and 17,5 m wide, which for the purpose of calculation has been divided into seven smaller plots because of its irregular surface.
1) Long sides in the West and the East: 700 cubits (350 m). Upper front in the North along the bank (kišādu) of the Banītu-Canal: 35 cubits (17,5 m). Lower front in the South bordering on the next plot (libbū eqli): 32 2/3 cubits (c. 16,3 m).
2) Long sides in the West and the East: 300 cubits (150 m). Upper front in the North bordering on the first measured area (mišihtu): 32 2/3 cubits (c. 16,3 m). Lower front in the South, adjacent to the next plot (libbū eqli): [x] cubits.
3) Long sides in the West and the East: 300 cubits (150 m). Upper front in the North bordering on the second measured area (mišihtu): [x] cubits. Lower front in the South, adjacent to the next plot (libbū eqli): 20 2/3 cubits (10,3 m).
4) Long sides in the West and the East: 300 cubits (150 m). Upper front in the North bordering on the third measured area (mišihtu): 20 2/3 cubits (c. 10,3 m). Lower front in the South, adjacent to the next plot (libbū eqli): 16 1/2 cubits (c. 8,25 m).
5) Long sides in the West and the East: 300 cubits (150 m). Upper front in the North bordering on the fourth measured area (mišihtu): 16 1/2 cubits (c. 8,25 m). Lower front in the South, adjacent to the next plot (libbū eqli): 10 cubits (5 m).
6) Long sides in the West and the East: 300 cubits (150 m). Upper front in the North bordering on the fifth measured area (mišihtu): 10 cubits (5 m). Lower front in the South, adjacent to the next plot (libbū eqli): 3 1/3 cubits (1,66 m).
7) Long sides in the West and the East: 250 cubits (125 m). Upper front in the North bordering on the sixth measured area (mišihtu): 3 1/3 cubits (1,66 m). In the South: triangular shaped  (santakku).
No witnesses, no scribe.

elementText.text:
Purchase of land.
A purchases 1 Kor (13500 m2) of agricultural land (zēru) from B: it is a cultivated date garden (kirû gišimmarē zaqpi) located in Qalunu, in the district (pīhatu) of Kutha. Its upper side borders on the field which is part of D’s dowry (nudunnû) and its lower side on (the property of) the sons of E; its upper front is adjacent to uncultivated (lā zaqpi) waterlogged land (kalû) and its lower front borders on (the property of) F. The seller, B, shares the property of this land together with his younger brother C. A declares the equivalent for this land together with the seller (A itti B mahīra nabû išām) to be 1 shekel of silver for each 7 1/2 GAR (56,25 m2), for a total purchase price (šīmišu gamrūtu) corresponding to 4 minas of silver. B acknowledges that he has received (mahāru) 1 mina and 40 shekels from A. It is followed by a remark concerning 2 minas of silver […] (owed) to G, who has taken this field as a pledge (maškanu). After they will have measured (mašāhu) this field and sealed the tablet (kanāku), A will give 20 shekels, what remains of the purchase price, to B. They have taken an oath (zakāru) by the gods and the king. Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; B = Nergal-zēru-ibni/Nergal-uballiṭ//Sagdidi; C = Taqīša-Gula/Nergal-uballiṭ//Sagdidi; D = Balāṭu/Kudurru; E = Ṭābiḫu; F = Kabtia/Nādin//Suhāya; G = Bēl-iddin

elementText.text:
Promissory note for dates, barley, silver and onions. Pledge of estate.
B owes 44;4.0.0 kor of dates, 2;3.2.0 kor of barley, 5 1/2 shekels of silver (and) 13 bundles (pītu) of onions to A, slave of C. The full amount (gamru) of dates is due in Tašrīt (VII) of the 5th year and should be delivered in one payment according to the 36 liters measure at the Borsippa canal; the silver and onions are due in Nisan (I); and the barley is due in Ayyār (II) and the full amount (gamru) should be delivered in one payment. The debtor's pledged two plots of land to the creditor in the past and these remain pledged. It concerns a field (eqlu) planted with date palms (bīt gišimmarē) located at the Borsippa canal, (and) the ... [broken off] planted with date palms (bīt gišimmarē zaqpu) and grain (pî šulpi) that extends to the village .... [broken off] and is probably next to the fields of the the temples of Bēl and Nabû. No other creditor shall exercise any rights over the pledged property until the creditor has received the full repayment of his silver. In addition, there is a previous claim by the same creditor for 80 kor of dates (and) a broken amount of silver that is related to an exchange deal (šupêltu). Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe's name: Bēl-ibni/...nāya.

A = Nergal-rēṣūa, slave of Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; B = Nergal-nāṣir/Nādinu; C = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn

elementText.text:
Receipt for silver. Purchase price for land.
A, acting as C’s proxy (ina našparti), receives (mahāru) 3 minas of medium quality silver, of which 1/8 is alloy, from B. This is the price paid for a plot of arable land (zēru) that is situated “between the gates” (ina birīt abullāti) and adjacent to C’s land. Names of 6 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Kināya/Bēl-ušallim//Sîn-tabni; B = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; C = Ardia/Šamaš-erība.

Establishment of a business partnership (harranu).
A1 and A2 agree that they will share equally in whatever they make with the 1 mina of silver that they invested in their joint business partnership. Names of xxx witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1= Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; A2= Šāpik-zēri/Nabû-šumu-iddin//Nādin-še'im

elementText.text:
Receipt for dates and barley. Payment of two separate debts.
Concerns the debt (u'iltu) of 24 kor of dates that B owes to A and for which there exists a written agreement (šaṭaru) with respect to the terms for repayment (adannu ana eṭēri). A receives (eṭēru) the 24 kor of dates and its interest from B. He undertakes to bring the promissory note about this debt and return it to B (našû-nadānu) before the end of Arahsamna (VIII). Concerning another debt
The present document also mentions a debt (u'iltu) of 4;1.1 kor of barley that C owes to B, who receives payment (eṭēru) for it from A. The parties to the contract have taken one copy of the document each. Names of 8 witnesses and the scribe: Nabû-balāssu-iqbi//Dābibi.
 
A = Nabû-bullissu/Nabû-šumu-uṣur//Bēl-aplu-uṣur; B = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; C = Nabû-mukīn-zēri/Nabû-šumu-līšir//Bēl-aplu-uṣur

elementText.text:
Delivery of dates
A1 and A2 will register (uzuzzu) 2;0.3 kor of dates till the 20th day of Kislīm (IX) of the 14th year of king Darius in B’s accounts and give (nadānu) proof of registration to C (B’s brother). They will register the second load of dates with D. Once they have registered this delivery by the end of Kislīm (IX), they will hoe (herû) the arable land (zēru) of the neighbours and he will release (paṭāru) to them 1 kor of field for 3 kor of dates. Should they fail to register, they will have to deliver (nadānu) 2.0.3 kor of dates between (ultu) the 26th day of Arahsamna (VIII) till the end of Ṭebēt (X). They guarantee for each other. The next two line are partly broken, legible are 30 shekels of silver and the name of A2. Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1 = Madānu-iddin; A2 = Itti-Nabû-gûzu; B = Puršu/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; C = Marduk-nāṣir-apli(/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi); D = Bēl-ittannu (without affliation)

elementText.text:
About a slave sale: receipt of purchase price and transfer of the silver to a third party.
A receives (mahāru) 45 shekels of silver from B, it being the purchase price for his slave C; this sum does not include (elat) 6 shekels of silver paid previously. This silver is is used to pay off D, the creditor (rāšû) of the seller's brother (E). Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Arad-Marduk/Šamaš-pir'a-uṣur//Eppeš-ilī; B = Dummuqu/Bēl-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; C = Madān-bēlu-uṣur; D = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; E = Rēmūt-Bēl/Šamaš-pir'a-uṣur/Eppeš-ilī, brother of A

elementText.text:
Adoption. Fragmentary.
Fragment of a tablet written in Hursagkalamma. fA adopts B1 and B2: she has out of her free will [sealed?] the adoption contract (ṭuppi mārûti) … Rest broken off. Scribe: Nergal-šumu-iddin /Šumu-uṣur/Bēl-ahu(?).
 
fA =  fDamqāya/Ina-tēšê-ēṭir//Marduku; B1 = Šala-bēl-bīti; B2 = Zababa-iddin

elementText.text:
Receipt for silver. Purchase price for a house.
A has purchased (ina qātē mahāru) a built house (bītu epšu) of 7;0.5.18 gi (c. 85 m2) on behalf of C1 and his wife fC2 from B. The house is located in the garden belt (erṣet kirûti) of Borsippa. A paid (nadānu) the full purchase price (gamru), 11 ½ minas of silver, with silver he got from C1 and fC2. However, he is not entitled to the house, nor to the silver. He gave the sale document that he sealed (with the seller) in name of C1 and fC2. Should a copy of this sealed sale document or any other legal document (riksu) about this house be found in A’s house or elsewhere, it belongs to C1 and fC2.
 
A = Madān-šumu-iddin/Zēria//Nabāya; B = Ibāya/Ṣillāya//Nagāru; C1 = Apla-dād-natan/Addia; fC2 = fBunanītu/Hariṣāya, wife of C1

elementText.text:
About household utensils from a dowry. Very fragmentary.
This fragmentary document concerns the dowry  (nudunnu) of fA consisting of (a.o.) 2 minas of low quality (hāṭu) silver, 1 mina [broken off], 1 bed (eršu), a roll (kerku) of HUM.HUM textile(s), clothing (muṣiptu), 10 mu-x-ha/ṣa-nu, (and) 1 bronze mukarrisu weighing ½ … She brought (erēbu Š) these items from (ultu) x-uš-x-…D (= the house of her father?) Then two men (B and C), one of them being a courtier (rēš šarri) are mentioned in a badly preserved passage. Whatever in addition (mimma mala elat) till the 10th of Šabāṭ (XI) E … from … fA to … Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe: Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi.
 
fA= Baṭû; B = Nergal-šarru-uṣur/…; C= Nazia (rēš šarri); D= Nabû-šimanni (or: …./ Nabû-šimanni), father of fA(?); E= Mušēzib-Bēl/…

elementText.text:
About the purchase of land: provisions for measurement and possible adjustment of purchase price.
Two brothers, A and B, sell land, which they own together. A sells 1 Kor (13500 m2) of land planted with trees (zēru zaqpu) located on the New Canal, including B‘s share (zittu), to C; B sells 1 Kor (13500 m2) of land planted with trees (zēru zaqpu) in Bīt-Hahhuru, including A’s share, to D. The brothers will measure (mašāhu) these fields and, should they be found larger or smaller, they will compensate each other (ahāmiš apālu). Apparently there are some doubts about the size of the second plot and therefore B should (re-)measure (mašāhu) the entire land in Bīt-Hahhuru and, should A's share in it be found larger or smaller than 1 kor, the brothers will compensate each other (ahāmiš apālu) according to their shares (zīzātu). The parties to the contract have taken one copy of the document each. Names of 11 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; B = Nergal-ušēzib/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; C = Bēl-iddin/Sîn-ēreš//Ibni-ilu; D = Mušēzib-Marduk/Bēlšunu//Ṭābih-kāri

elementText.text:
Sale of slaves.
The tablet, drafted in Humadēšu and subsequently brought to Babylonia (Stolper 1984, pp. 306f and n. 31) presents several Iranian names and titles, and it is ascribable to the Egibi archive based on the buyer’s name (Zadok 1976, p. 73). A, a magi(?) (wr. ma-gi-ia) (and) merchant (tamkāru), sells 2 slaves (ardu) C1 and C2 for 2 minas 40 shekels of silver to B. The purchase is witnessed by D1, chief merchant (rab tamkāri), D2, overseer of the regular dues (ša muhhi ginê), D3 and D4, city governor(?) (uppadētu) of the country Humadēšu. Note that these persons are not explicitly introduced as "witness". On the edge of the tablet there is a date (month/day/year) which gives no reference to a king.
 
A = Antumma’/Barzu, b/magia tamkāru; B = Bagapāta/Nabû-zēr-iqīša; C1 = Ataršitra’; C2 = Rātakka’/Razamumarga’; D1 = Atrarušu (wr. Ar-ta-ru!-us), chief merchant (rab tamkāri); D2 = Atēamuštu, overseer of the regular dues (ša muhhi ginê); D3 = Bagasaru (wr. ba-ga-a-a’-si-ru-u’)/Humagammu; D4 = Umar’mira’, city governor(?) (uppadētu) of the country Humadēšu

elementText.text:
Sale of two persons (slaves?)
The brothers A1 and A2 sell fC1 and her young (ṣeḫru, wr. ṣa-ah-ru) son C2 (probably slaves, but not explicitly labelled as such) to B for 1 mina and 10 shekels of silver. The sellers guarantee against (suits brought by) a person acting unlawfully (sēhû) or a person claiming (pāqirānu) that the sold slaves are royal slaves (arad šarrūtu) or free person (mār banê). This sale is to be kept apart from the debt (u’iltu) of 2 minas of silver that A1 still owes (to the sellers). Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe: Arad-Marduk/Kittia//Šangû-Ea
 
A1 = Nabû-ēreš/Tabnēa!//Ahu-bāni; A2 = Nabû-šumu-iškun, brother of A1; B = Itti-Marduk-balātu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; fC1 = fBānītu-šulliminni (without affiliation); C2 = Nabû-rēmū’a, son of fC2.

elementText.text:
Receipt
A1 and A2 receive (mahāru) 1 mina 46 1/2 shekels of silver from fB1 for her husband’s (B2) urāšu-obligation from (ultu) Arahsamna (VIII) of the 1st year till (adi) the 13th day of Abu (V) of the 2nd year. Each of the parties have a copy of the present document at their disposal (ina pāni). This is in addition to (elat) the promissory note (u’iltu) for kiln-fired bricks (agurru) that is recorded (e’elû) between the same parties. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1 = Nabû-bāni-zēri/Dajjānu-Marduk/Sîn-šadûnu; A2 = Šamaš-šuma-ukīn; fB1 = fIna-Esagila-ramât/Zēria//Nabāya; B2 = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn

elementText.text:
Asset transfer.
A, of his own free will (ina hūd libbišu), transfers (dagālu Š, emendation) the ownership of his assets to his son B. The property consists of 1 sq. kor (c. 13500 m2) of arable land (zēru), a field planted with date palms (eqel gišimmarē zaqpu) bearing fruit (iṣṣi bilti), and 2 sq. kor (c. 27000 m2) of a plot of ploughed land (eqel mērešu). The total amount corresponds to 3 kor (c. 40500 m2) of arable land (zēru): this is located in Til-bēlšunu, in the district (pīhātu) of Babylon, from the bank of the Euphrates for a total extension (šalāmu G) of 3 kor (c. 40500 m2) of land cultivated with trees and grain (zēru zaqpu u mērešu). This property had been given in exchange for (kūm) arable land (zēru) located at the outlet (bābu) of the Old Kutha Canal that belonged to fC’s (i.e. A’s wife) dowry, who died (lit: “whom the destiny has carried away, ša šīmtu abālu). In the final, fragmentary section of the text there is reference to another plot of land: this was sold (ana kaspi nadānu) by A to D and apparently was shared by E and his brothers. Then, someone’s daughter is mentioned: she seems to obtain the property of something (dagālu Š), but details are lost because of the poor state of conservation of the lower part of this tablet. Names of 5 witnesses and the scribe: Kabti-ilī-Marduk//Atkuppu.
 
A = Šamaš-aplu-uṣur/Šamaš-ina-tēšê-ēṭir//Šangû-Šamaš; B = Nabû-aplu-iddin, son of A; fC = fAmat-Ninlil(//Šangû-Šamaš), wife of A; D = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; E = Nergal-ušallim (without affiliation, probably Nergal-ušallim//Šangû-Šamaš and a brother of either A or his wife. E's son, Nabû-rēmanni, is among the witnesses).

elementText.text:
Rent of livestock.
A rents out (ana zitti nadānu) 30 she-goats (enzētu), 5 he-goats (enzū, wr. ùz.maš.gal), 20 young ewes (lahru tālittu) and 5 female lambs (parratu), 60 living beings (napištu) in total, to B (C’s slave) for 1 mina and 20 shekels of silver. The renter receives 20 shekels of silver, from the share held by (pūt zitti ša) B; the tenant will give the remaining 20 shekels of silver in the month Simān (III). B guarantees for the herding (re’ītu), caretaking (suddudu) and guarding (maṣṣartu) (of this livestock). They hold an equal share (ahātu) in the young animals (tālittu) and the shorn wool (gizzatu). The flock (ṣēnu) is (part of) the business capital (harrānu) of D, the šušānu-officer of Nabonidus. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Barīk-ilī/Nabû-zēru-ibni; B = Arad-Bēl, slave of C; C = Iddin-Marduk; D = Nusku-ēdu-uṣur, šušānu-officer

elementText.text:
Promissory note for the production of hides, part of a business partnership
B owes 1 mina of silver to A. He should use it to make tanned hides (ṣallu) which he should  then deliver (nadānu) to A. In return, he will enjoy (akālu) a half share (ahu) in the profits (utru) of this business, together with (itti!, T, [e]-li) A, and a monthly income of 0;1.4 barley and ⌈UL? IŠ?⌉ ul ⌈te pu⌉. He acknowledges that he has already received (mahāru) 20 shekels of silver out of (ina libbi) the 1 mina. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe: Šāpik-zēri /Nabû-šumu-iddin//Nādin-še’im.
 
A = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; B = Iddin-Nabû/Bēl-nā’id//Atamaranussu

elementText.text:
Promissory note for silver. Antichretic pledge of a slave.
B owes ½ minas of silver to A. The payment is secured by the pledge of the debtor’s slave (C). A’s income from the slave’s work pays for the interest (antichresis) and he is exempt from paying rent for the slave. Should the pledged slave go to another place, the debtor shall pay 3 liters (qû) of barley on a daily basis to A as compensatory payment (mandattu) for his loss of income from the absent slave. The document no doubt belongs to the Egibi/Nūr-Sîn archive. Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe: Sîn-erība/Sîn-ahu-iddin.
 
A = Šullumu/Mušēzib-Bēl; B = Mušēzib-Marduk/Ardia//Ēṭiru; C = Madān-šarru-uṣur, slave of B

elementText.text:
Undertaking to warrant. Partly unclear.
Document opens with a reference to a warranty(?) (pu-ut, partly reconstructed) for the sa-ra-qu (=donation/theft?, uncl.) by/of fB that A assumes(?) (l. 3 n[a-ši]) towards Ninlil. He has given D as pledge to C1 and C2 till Arahsamna (VIII), till(?) … (adi muhhi x x iš, uncl.)  B will have stolen/donated(?)(šarāq/ku, wr. ta-šar-ra-qu). Before (ina pāni) the 4 judges E1-4, followed by an obscure passage referring to an additional promissory note being … (u’iltu elat qí-it [(…)]. There is no list of witnesses. The scribe is Gimil-Gula/Šākin-šumi//Mudammiq-Adad.
 
A =  Kabtia/Mušallim-Marduk//Bēl-ēṭir; fB = fBāba-bēlet; C1 = Nabû-balāssu-iqbi/Nabû-mukīn-apli; C2 = Nabû-mušētiq-uddê/Nabû-mukīn-apli; D = Silim-Bēl; E1 = Mušēzib-Marduk; E2= Nergal-ušallim; E3= Nergal-bānûnu; E4= Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi.

elementText.text:
Deposition before witnesses about a delivery.
The tablet is badly preserved. A’s deposition is very fragmentary. Legible are the words barley (uṭṭatu), due from (ina muhhi), his impost (imittu), a blade of a plough (šinnu), and twice the verb "I gave".   
Apart from (elat) this, nothing is charged against him.
Up to (adi) … I will deliver (nādanu) to PN and will place it … After the list of witnesses, the name of the scribe, date and place A states that he sold (it) (ana kaspi nadānu) before Arahsamna (VIII) in the 19th year. Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe: Širku/Iddināya//Egibi.
 
A=Iddin-Bēl/Balāṭu//Rab…

elementText.text:
Purchase of land. Fragmentary.
The text records the purchase of x+0.1 Kor (2770+ m2) of arable land (zēru); data on the type and location are not preserved, except for the indication that it was in front of a city gate. A field belonging to A is mentioned in the opening lines in a broken context; then, the neighbouring properties are given. The upper long side in the North is adjacent to […], the lower long side in the South borders on (the property of) B; the upper front in the West borders on (the property of) C and the lower front in the East adjacent to [...]. Rest broken off. Names of 4 witnesses and 2 scribes.
 
A = Nabû-šumu-ukīn/Sîn-šadûnu//Ša-nāšīšu; B = Šāpik-zēri/Kudurru//…; C = Nummuru/Nergal- šumu-uṣur//…

elementText.text:
Sale of one or more slaves. Very fragmentary.
The beginning of the tablet is broken off, thus it is impossible to know how many slaves are sold. From what is extant it is clear that A sells someone to B, and he is also the one who guarantees against (suits brought by) a person acting unlawfully (sēhû) or a person claiming (pāqirānu) that the slave(s) is(are) a free person(s) (mār banê). Names of 2+ witnesses; name of the scribe broken off.
 
A = Nabû-uṣuršu/Balāṭu//Miṣirāya; B = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn

elementText.text:
Sale of a slave.
A, of his own free will, sells his female slave fC to B for a total purchase price amounting to 35 shekels of silver. The seller guarantees against (suits brought by) a person acting unlawfully (sēhû) or a person claiming (pāqirānu) that fC is a royal slave (amat šarrūtu) or a free person (mār banê). Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Lâbāši/Zēria//Nabāya; B = Bēl-iddin/Šāpik-zēri/Mudammiq-Adad; fC = fLā-qīptu

elementText.text:
Annulment of a slave sale.
A sold publicly (ina puhri, wr. pu-uh![T: UZ)-ru) one of his brother's female slaves (fC) for 1 1/3 minas and 5 shekels of silver to B. His brother (D) was not present (qerēbu) at the sale. He arranged that the sale document be written in D's name, his brother, and also the promissory note about 39 shekels which the buyer had still to pay was issued in D's name. E guaranteed for the female slave. Eventually, the sale is annulled so that D gets his slave back and B, the buyer, can ask for repayment (bu''û – esēru) of his silver from A.  The promissory note for the remainder of the purchase price, 39 shekels, has been returned by D to B. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe: Mušēzib-Marduk//…(uncl.)-Ea. See also BM31426.
 
A = Iddin-Nabû/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B = Marduk-ahu-uṣur/Šilāya; fC = fMiṣātu; D = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu(Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi), brother of A; E= Nabû-uballiṭ.

elementText.text:
Land rental.
A rents 0;1.4 Kor (4500 m2) of land planted with trees (zēru zaqpu) adjacent to C1’s ‚and C2’s ditch for 5 years to B, who should perform gardening work (nukaribbūtu). He will plant trees (zaqāpu) on 0;0.1 Kor (450 m2): he will plant 30 fig trees, 20 trees of sweet pomegranates; 3 trees of sweet apples – all trees of good quality (babbanû) – and he will enclose them with a wall. In Abu (V), he should carry out the excavation work for irrigation, he is responsible for bringing water from the ditch in the center of the field drawing it from the previous canal. He will not cut off sprouts (raṭbu) nor […], he will not tear out spadices (kaparru). The landlord will give him 5 kor (900 l) of dates per kor of land, as gardener's remuneration (šissinnu). The renter is responsible for the tree planting (limītu): should he fail to do so, he shall pay 1 mina of silver. He will not chop down (marû D) the date palms which are spontaneously grown from seeds (gisimmaru za-ri-ti). B will enjoy one third of the trees' yield for 10 years, together with A. The parties to the contract have taken one copy of the document each. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Šāpik-zēri/Ṣillāya//Nabāya; B = Bēl-uballiṭ/Nabû-bēl-ilī//Rab-banê; C1 = Ina-qibi-Bēl/Balāṭu//Rē'i-sīsê; C2 = Bēl-nādin-apli/Talīmu

elementText.text:
Renewal of the pledge of a slave to secure a silver debt.
B1 and his wife (fB2) owe a broken amount of silver to A. The debtors’  slave, who had already been pledged to the creditor for an earlier promissory note, will remain pledged. No other creditor shall exercise any rights over the pledged slave until the debt is fully repaid. C1 and fC2 acts as guarantors for the payment. In addition, the debtors’s earlier debt is still pending, and the same is true for a debt owed by the guarantors (C1 and fC2) that is secured by their mutual warranty.
 
A = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; B1 = Šamaš-šumu-iddin/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Etellu; fB2 = fAmtia, wife of B1; C1 = Ardia; fC2= fTapaššara, wife of C1

elementText.text:
Sale of a slave. Purchase by proxy. Fragmentary.
A sold C, a slave, to B1 for a hariṣ-price amounting to 50 shekels of silver. it was B2 who provided (nadnu) the silver for the purchase, and the slave has accordingly been legally transferred to him (etēqu N). Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Nabû-ēreš/Tabnēa//Ahu-bāni; B1 = Bēlšunu/Bēl-ēṭir//Buraqqu; B2 = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; C = Nabû-dīni-epuš

elementText.text:
Deposition before the freemen (mār banê)
Dispute between C and B about the right to income from a field that B's father-in-law had pledged (bīt maškāni) to C. A, slave of C, made the following deposition (kullu) against (ana) B in the presence (ina pāni) of the freemen (mār-banê): "Concerning your father-in-law D’s estimated income from imposts (imittu): it belongs to us (anīni).”(*) B said as follows: I gave (nadānu) it to E". Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe. 
Notes(*): alternatively: “Concerning your father-in-law D’s income from imposts, B said to us as follows ….”
 
A = Madān-bēlu-uṣur; B = Kalbi-Bāba/Nabû-unamir; C = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; D = Nergal-nāṣir/Nādin; E = Nabū-ēṭir/Nergal-šumu-ibni

elementText.text:
Sale of a slave.
A, of his own free will, sells his female slave fC to B. The total purchase price amounts to 1 1/3 mina and 5 shekels of silver. The remainder of the text is broken off, including the list of witnesses and the scribe's name. A short remark after the date and place of issue points out that A's name is written (šaṭāru) on the slave's wrist(?) in cuneiform and alphabetic script (akkādîtu u ahlamāti). See also Liv019.
 
A = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B = Marduk-ahu-uṣur/Šilāya; fC = fMiṣatu

elementText.text:
House rental.
A rents one asuppu-building and one kāru-house to B, D’s slave. These buildings belongs to the cook of A's grandson (C).The rent is fixed at 0;0.2 kor (2 l) of bread per day. The house is at the renter’s disposal from the 2nd of Simān (III) onwards. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Šarid; B = Bēl-ṣullê-šeme; C = Šušranni-Marduk/Marduk-šumu-uṣur//Adad-šumu-ēreš; D = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi

elementText.text:
Payment to creditor after land purchase.
A1 and his mother fA2 sold 0;0.4.1.9 Kor (11925 m2) of land planted with trees (zēru zaqpu), located on the Bitqu-ša-Ile’’i-Bēl, to B for 42 shekels of silver. Out of this total amount, 35 shekels of silver have been given to fA2’s creditor (rāšû). B hands over to A1, son of fA2, the promissory notes (uˀilēti) for these 35 shekels of silver, that he held (išû). A1 will receive (eṭēru N) the remaining 9 shekels from B – not including (elat) the silver corresponding to the price (šīmu) of the yield (ebūru). Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1 = Nādin/Rēmūt//Eppeš-ilī; fA2 = fTašmētu-damqat, mother of A1; B = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi

elementText.text:
Purchase of land: agreement upon the price and the yield.
The document has been written to finalise the deal between fA and her brother B, after she acquired a field from him. The plot consists of 0;1.1.3 Kor (2275 m2) of agricultural land (zēru), a cultivated date garden (kirû gišimmarē zaqpi) bearing fruit (iṣṣi bilti) in front of the Uraš Gate.
Its upper side is adjacent to the course (alku) of the Madānu Canal, its lower side borders on (the property of) C; its upper front borders on (the property of) D and its lower front is again adjacent to C’s land. B acknowledges that he has given (nadānu) this land, all of it, to his sister fA for 35 shekels of silver as hariṣu-price – as established in a tablet (kî ṭuppi) that E, the royal scribe (ṭupšarru ša šarri), has sealed (kanāku). B has taken an oath (tamû) by the gods Bēl and Nabû to ensure that he did not act treacherously (niklu nakālu) by overrating (šaqû D) the silver. One final clause establishes that the yield (ebūru) of Nabonidus’ 16th year belongs to fA. Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe.
 
fA = fBu’itu/Nabû-bān-ahi//Šangû-Gula; B = Marduk-šumu-ibni/Nabû-bān-ahi//Šangû-Gula; C = Tabnēa; D = Bēl-iddin; E = Ṣillāya, royal scribe (ṭupšarru ša šarri)

elementText.text:
House rental: receipt of rental payment.
A confirms that he has received an unknown amount of silver (the amount is lost in a lacuna) from B, C’s slave, as rental payment for his house from [x] (details lost) to Tašrīt (VII) of an unknown Cambyses’ regnal year. Kislīm (IX) is mentioned in a broken context. The parties to the contract have taken one copy of the document each. Names of x witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Itti-Nabû-balāṭu/Šar-ahhēšu//Egibi; B = Nabû-uballiṭ/…, slave of C; C = Iqbi-Bēl

elementText.text:
Distribution of land: fields plan.
The text provides details for the allocation of land: on the obverse of the tablet there is a plan that shows six plots of land separated by a canal, with the exact measurements of the lenght for each one of their sides and the total surface areas. On the edges of the tablets there are the neighbouring properties. The reverse records how these shares are assigned to two individuals, an uncle and his nephew.
A takes possesion (ṣabātu) of the upper share (zittu elītu), which is located above and below the New Canal and that borders the land of C1, an oblate (širku) of Marduk, C2 und C3. The surface area is described in detail in the first lines of the reverse: the area above the canal consists of 1;0.2.4.2 kor (14715 m2) of land (zēru) of which 0;3.2.5.2 kor (9390 m2) are land planted with trees (zēru zaqpu) – while the area below the canal consists of 5;1.2.2.5 kor (71287,5 m2) of land (zēru), of which 1;1.5.3.8 kor (18735 m2) are land planted with trees (zēru zaqpu). This calculation includes also the area between the fields (adi birat).
B, the nephew, takes possesion (ṣabātu) of the lower share (zittu šaplītu), which is also located above and below the New Canal and that borders the land of fD. The surface area of this share is described in detail in the opening lines of the reverse: the area above the canal consists of 1;0.2.3.6 kor (14670 m2) of land (zēru), of which 0;3.2.2.6 kor (9195 m2) are land planted with trees (zēru zaqpu) – while the area below the canal consists of 5;0.5.4.5 kor (70087,5 m2) of land (zēru) of which 1;2.1.5.5 (19762,5 m2) are land planted with trees (zēru zaqpu). As in the previous case, these numbers include the area between the fields (adi birat).
A and B promise that they will not withhold (kalû) water nor access to the land (mê u muṣû) to each other; the text records that they have taken one copy of the document each. Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe.
The land assigned to A corresponds to plots 1a, 2a and 3a while B’s share corresponds to 1b, 2b and 3b in Wunsch’s drawing (Wunsch 2000, vol. 1, p. 195). The detailed contract for this deal is recorded in BM30365 + BM32216.
 
A = Nergal-ēṭir; B = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; C1 = Nabû-uballiṭ/Kuššāya, oblate (širku) of Marduk; C2 = Tabnēa/Nabû-aplu-iddin; C3 = Nabû-tabni-uṣur/Rēmūt; fD = fBarsippītu/Arad-Marduk//Ile''i-Marduk

elementText.text:
Fragmentary promissory note.
Most of the tablet is broken. Only one sentence can be reconstructed. This is that he (name broken) shall pay the silver in Babylon in Addar (XII). Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn acts as witness. The names of the other witnesses and the scribe are broken.

elementText.text:
Establishment of a business partnership (harranu).
A1 and A2 establish a business partnership (ana harrāni šakānu) and each of them invest 50 kor of dates. The partners agree that they will share equally (ahata-šunu) in whatever they make (verb in the sg.) in or out of town with the mentioned dates. A1's and his brothers' house in Borsippa located next to the house of the rab unqati-official is rented to A2 for ½ minas of silver and 1 gullenu of upper-garment annual rent. After […] (ár-{a}-ki mu x x) the house stands at A2’s disposal. The house rent will be paid (eṭēru N) from the business partnership's assets (ultu harrani). A1 will provide household utentils (udû bīti) to A2. At the end of the year, A2 has to return the mentioned utensils to A1. The parties to the contract have taken one copy of the document each. The southern part of the house will remain at A1’s diposal. Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe: Marduk-bēlšunu/….
 
A1= Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; A2 = Bēl-iqīša/Lâbāši//Pahāru

elementText.text:
Loan of millstones.
A will place at B’s disposal (ina pāni nadānu) a mill (ararru) for cumin (hašimuru, wr. na4.har ša ḫaš-ši-ur) and an upper millstone (naškabu); in exchange, B will deliver (nadānu) each month 0;4 kor (c. 144 l.) of pure dinû flour to A. B guarantees not to break (ḫepû) the mill and the upper millstone (naškabu). Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; B = Atkal-ana-Marduk

elementText.text:
Receipt
A receives (mahāru) from B, the slave of C, payment for D’s urāšu-obligation till (adi) the 3rd day of Simān (III) of the 6th year. The document is dated in Ayyār (II). Names of 2 witnesses, a.o. Zababa-šarru-uṣur/Gimillu, a harbor-master (rab kāri) and the scribe: Bēl-iddin/Nabû-ēṭir//Rab-banê .
 
A= Nummuru/Zēria; B= Nergal-rēṣua; C= Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; D=Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya

elementText.text:
Summon/Injunction
By Nisan (I) of Neriglissar’s 4th regnal year, fA will give back 1 1/3 mina of silver to B: this sum corresponds to the purchase price for fC1, fC2, fC3 and C4, her domestic staff (nišū bīti). Should fA fail to pay B by Nisan (I), then he will record the price for these servants in his promissory note. If by Nisan (I) she has not (yet) given these (sold) servants to B, fA will have to immediately give the silver back to him. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
fA = fNuptāya/Marduk-šumu-ibni//Pahāru; B = Nādinu/Šulāya//Amelu; fC1 = fBānitu; fC2 = broken name; fC3 = fŠī-lū-dārat; C4 = Nabû-rēmu-šukun

elementText.text:
Court protocol: litigation about a house.
fA has brought a suit against B in front of C and the other judges because of a house that she bought with money she borrowed (habātu D) from B. The house is located on the Hubur Street, near D’s house (which was given to E, the Persian), and near the house of F, G’s slave. fA has the purchase document (ṭuppu bīti) that proves her title to this house. Now B wants to be paid back, and therefore he is summoned to testify (ana dīni abālu D) in his own case (eli ramānišu kânu D). The text at the end is slightly broken but eventually  it is stated that the house belongs to B and fA has no share in it. Names of 12 witnesses (including B’s brother, Nergal-ušēzib) and the scribe.
 
fA = fIna-Esagila-rāmat/Zēria//Nabāya; B = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; C = Itti- Nabû-balāṭu; D = Zumbāya/Mušallim-Marduk; E = Partâmu, the Persian; F = Girāya; G = Nabû-bān-ahi

elementText.text:
Hire of a slave. Fragmentary.
A leases a slave (C) to B for an annual payment of 9 shekels of silver. Half the rent should be paid in the middle of the year, the rest at the end of the year. Remainder is broken off. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe: Nabû-ṭabtani-uṣur/Kittia//Šangû-Ea
 
A = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B = Ina-ṣilli-Bēl; C = Bar-imu(?), slave of A

elementText.text:
Promissory note for silver, capital of a business dealing in wine.
B owes 2 minas and 4 shekels of silver to A1 and A2. The three men will enjoy the profits of B’s business according  to their shares (in the business). C, slave of A1 will work with B in the business (našpartu alāku) and B guarantees for the return of the capital amount of the silver. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1 = Nabû-zēru-iqīša/Bēl-aplu-iddin//Egibi; A2 = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B = Nabû-šumu-udammiq/Nabû-nādin-šumi//Ilī-ellatu; C = Dihummu, slave of A1.

elementText.text:
Promissory note for silver without interest.
B owes 1 mina and 4 shekels of silver to A, to be paid without interest in Simān (III).
In addition, there is an earlier claim (by the same creditor) (rašûtu); and there are also accounts that he booked with C and D (itti našû) and that still need to be settled (rēhet nikkassi) but for which there are no written records (ša lā u'iltu). Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe: Šumāya/Šulāya//Itinnu.

A = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; B = Šumu-iddin/Marduk-šarrani//Šallala; C = Bēl-ibni; D = Nergal-rēṣūa

elementText.text:
Promissory note for silver, within the framework of a business partnership (harrānu). With pledge of houses and warranty clause.
The present record, formulated as a standard promissory note, documents a business partnership agreement and is mainly concerned about securing repayment of the invested capital. 40 shekels of silver of which one-eighth is alloy, are owed to fA by fB1 and her son (B2) from the capital that E invested in a business partnership (with them). The house at the bridge is pledged to the creditor. It is located next to C, the debtor's husband and belongs to her dowry. She transferred ownership over it to her son (B2) in a sealed document. It measures 2 gar. Pledged is further a house of 2 gar owned by B2 in which the creditor is actually living. fB1 assumes warranty for the repayment of the 40 shekels. fA should pay rent to C, husband of fB1, on a yearly basis.The house will be her disposal from the 1st of §abaṭ (XI), i.e. next month. She should renew the roof within 6 years. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe: Nabû-aplu-iddin/Nabû-[dāmiq]//Banâ-ša-ilia

fA = fAmat-Ninlil/Zēr-Bābili//Pahāru; fB1 = fṬābatu/Bēl-ahhē-erība//Ša-ṭābtišu; B2 = Nabû-uballiṭ, son of fA; C = Gimillu, husband of fB1; E = Nabû-dāmiq

elementText.text:
Undertaking to stand warranty as long as the original guarantor is abroad.
A stands warranty for her husband B as long as his brother C has not yet returned from the other side (ahulla) of the river. When he returns, she will bring him to PN (name broken off) and hand him over to him (abāku – nadānu). Names of 2 witnesses: Šalammānu/Baltumu, a royal merchant (tamkar šarri), and Bēl-ēṭir/Nergal-abu-uṣur; and the scribe: Nabû-zēru-iddin/Iššar-iddin. The text may belong to the Egibi archive. There is an Aramaic epigraph: pnbṭm פנבטם
 
fA = fBurāšu (without affiliation); B = Ilī-qanûa (without affiliation); C= Pān-Nabû-ṭēmu, brother of B

elementText.text:
Exchange of land with equalizing payment.
The document records the exchange (ṭuppu šupêltu) of land planted with trees (zēru zaqpu) and a grain field (pî šulpu) that A and fB have switched with each other (ahāmiš šupêlu).
The first land, which belongs to fB, consists of 6 Kor (81000 m2), partly land planted with trees (zēru zaqpu) and partly cultivated as well as newly cleared land (mērešu u taptû) located above and below the New Canal  in front of the Enlil Gate in the district (pīhatu) of Babylon. Its upper side borders on (the property of) C1, C2 and C3, an oblate (širku) of Marduk, its lower side on (the property of) A and his brothers. The second property, owned by A, consists of 2 Kor (27000 m2) of land planted with trees (zēru zaqpu) located above and below the Zalmunitu ditch (harru) in front of the Ebišu Gate, in the district (pīhatu) of Dilbat. Its upper side is adjacent to (the property of) D1 and D2, the Aramaean, its lower side borders on (the propery of) E1, E2 and E3; its upper front is adjacent to (the property of) F and the lower front to (the property of) G1, G2 and G3.
A and fB exchange these fields with each other (ahāmiš šupêlu). Accordingly, A takes possession (ana muhhi elû) of the land on the New Canal and fB of the one in Dilbat. Since A only gives 2 kor of land  but receives 6 kor, he has to compensate for the difference (takpuštu), by paying 4 minas of medium quality silver, of which 1/8 is alloy, to fB. However, this payment is in a sense fictive, because fB eventually never got the silver, even if the text explicitly states that she received it (eṭēru). In fact, 2 minas and 30 shekels A could keep to cover fB's debt to him (for which he already took the house near I 's house as pledge (maškanu ṣabātu);  the remaining 1 mina and 30 shekels of white silver (kaspa peṣû) are given to fK, the creditor (rāšû) of fB and her husband H. L, fB’s brother, guarantees that H's daughter will not complain (lā ragāmu) about the silver that A receives as as equalizing payment (takpuštu) from fB. The parties to the contract have taken one copy of the document each. Names of 10 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; fB = fSūqā'ītu/Itti-Nabû-balāṭu//Egibi, wife of H; C1 = Tabnēa/Nabû-aplu-iddin; C2 = Nabû-tabni-uṣur/Rēmūt; C3 = Nabû-uballiṭ, oblate (širku) of Marduk; D1 = Nabû-zēru-ušabši/Nabû-ēṭir-napšāti; D2 = Šam-ilī; E1 = Nabû-zēru-iqīša/Eppeš-ilī; E2 = Lagamal-iddin/Uraš-iddin; E3 = Nabû-balāssu-iqbi; F = Bēl-īpuš/Lagamal-iddin; G1 = Nabû-zēru-iqīša/Nabû-zēru-ukīn; G2 = Nabû-ittannu/Kināya; G3 = Šumu-uṣur/Nabû-ušallim; H = Nergal-ēṭir, husband of fB; I = Bēl-iddin/Dēkû; fK = fSagilāya; L = Nabû-zēru-ibni/Itti-Nabû-balāṭu//Egibi

Receipt
A receives (mahāru) 10 shekels of silver from fB for C’s tax payment to finance work (dullu). This is in addition to previous receipts (giṭṭu). Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Nūrea/Bēl-iqīša(//Šangû-Nanāya); fB = fIna-Esagila-ramât; C = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn, husband of fB

elementText.text:
Asset transfer.
A, of his own free will (ina hūd libbišu), transmits all his assets to his father B under a sealed document (kanāku - dagālu Š). The property consists of all that C, his mother’s father, and fD, the mother of his grandmother fE, left to F (son of their daughter) as recorded in a sealed document. Now, A transfers the property of all the assets described in that previous document issued by C and fD – including fields (eqlu), houses (bītu) and slaves (amīlūtu) – to his father B, for ever (ana ūmī ṣâti). As long as A will live, these fields, houses, slaves and all his property (nikkassu) will remain at his disposal, as established in the tablet. The text ends with the usual curse formulas against whomever will change the words written in the agreement. Names of 5 witnesses and the scribe: Šamaš-zēru-ušabši/Zāriqu-zēri//Rab-banê.
The tablet is oriented in a landscape format, and it is not sealed: no doubt it is a copy made for the Egibi family.
 
A = Nabû-aplu-iddin/Šamaš-aplu-uṣur//Šangû-Šamaš; B = Šamaš-aplu-uṣur/Šamaš-ina-tēšê-ēṭir//Šangû-Šamaš, father of A; C = Nabû-balāssu-iqbi/Nūrēa//Šangû-Šamaš, grandfather of A; fD = fKabtāya, mother of fE; fE = fAmat-Ninlil, grandmother of A; F = Nabû-aplu-iddin, nephew of A

elementText.text:
Adjustment of livestock.
A, B’s messenger (mār šipri), in the presence of (lapāni) C lead away (abāku) 2 sheep from the open country (ṣēru) and entrusted (paqādu) them to D, E’s slave. Now, B leads away (abāku) from E (some) sheep in exchange (šupêltu); E also reaches an agreement (with B) (izuzzu Š) with regards to the 55 1/4 shekels of his silver, that are at B’s disposal. A line written on the upper edge of the tablet defines it as a memorandum (tahsistu) written not to forget. Names of 4 witnesses. No scribe.
 
A = Nabû-kāṣir, messenger of B; B = Lâbāši; C = Nergal-ahui-ddin; D = Arad-Nabû, slave of E; E = Iddin-Marduk

element.description: A name given to the resource

element.name: Museum No.
element.description: Museum number of cuneiform tablet

elementText.text:
Promissory note for silver. Antichretic pledge of a house.
B owes 2 ½ minas of silver to A. The debtor’s house located next to C’s house is pledged to the creditor for two years in lieu of paying interest (antichretic pledge). Thus, the creditor does not have to pay house rent. Apart from this silver debt, A may not give silver to B without informing B’s brother (D), otherwise he will lose that silver. Furthermore, A should not leave the house without D’s permission. Names of 4 witnesses and in the presence (ina ašābi) of B’s mother. Scribe's name: Šumu-iškun/Nergal-ašarēdu//Rē'i-sīsê
 
A = Nergal-ušezib/…-zu; B = Iddin-Nabû/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; C = Bēl-iddin/Rēmūt/Edku; D = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi, brother of B

element.description: Museum number of cuneiform tablet

elementText.text:
Promissory oath. Undertaking to pay off debts.
A swears (tamû) by Bēl, Nabû and king Darius to B: "I will deliver (nadānu) to B up to (adi) the 12th day of Arahsamna (VIII) B’s 0;3.2 kor of dates at my disposal." If A fails to meet the deadline, he will pay B on the 5th day of the month (broken) 4 shekels of silver. Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe. A 5th witness is added at the very end of the document, after the place and date of issue.
 
A = Tabnēa/Marduk-šumu-iddin//Ša-našīšu; B = Širku/Iddināya//Egibi

elementText.text:
The document opens by listing three items, boat appurtenances, which are together valued (manû) at 1 mina of silver: a mounted canopy (maškanu šuršudu), sails (or screens?) (paruktu), and a leather canvas (kutummu ša maški). Then a boat (eleppu) is mentioned, whose price is calculated (manû) at  ½ mina of silver and in which A1, A2 and A3 have each a one-third share (šullultāti zittu). The remainder of the text is fragmentary: Nabû-uterri, slave (ardu) of A2, … from A2 ½ mina of silver … . The document was issued before (pāni) 5 individuals, without affiliation: B1-5, all judges in Babylon. Followed by the names of 2 scribes, also without affiliation: Nabû-kāṣir and Bēl-iddin. Place and date. Seal impression of 4 of the 5 judges (excl. Rīmūt-Bēl).
 
A1 = Nabû-balāssu-iqbi/Dayyān-Marduk//Šangû; A2 = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; A3 = Erība-Marduk/Nergal-bānûnu//Rab-banê. Judges (dayyānu): B1 = Nergal-ušallim; B2 = Nabû-šumu-līšir; B3= Rēmūt-Bēl; B4 = Nabû-x-iq-ilī; B5 = Marduk-šumu-iddin

elementText.text:
Establishment of a business partnership (harranu).
A invests a certain amount of silver (details n/a) in a business partnership with B. The latter shall run the business and will be entitled to a third share in the profits. He will be accountable for overspending money on expenses (ana etēqi etēqu). In addition, he should provide A yearly with a túgKUR.RA-garment worth 2 shekels from the business capital.
 
A = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; B = Mušēzib-Marduk/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Qaqqadanītu
